story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsMore than a million people backed&nbspthe call for a public vote on Theresa May’s Brexit deal in just three monthsClick to followIndy PoliticsThe Independent’s petition for a Final Say referendum has been revealed as the most popular UK petition all year, as new polling shows the&nbspmajority of voters feel they have been cut out of the&nbspBrexit&nbspprocess.More than a million people backed the call for a public vote on Theresa May’s Brexit deal in just three months, after deadlock&nbspin talks with Brussels&nbspand growing concerns over the prospect of a&nbspno-deal Brexit.Change.org, the world’s largest petition platform, said&nbspBrexit was dominating&nbsppublic opinion and&nbspThe Independent’s Final Say petition was the biggest UK campaign it&nbsphad hosted in 2018.Everyone feels cut out the Brexit process – even LeaversIt comes as a&nbspnew poll by&nbspthe influential site found that more than 85 per cent of voters felt they had been ignored over&nbspthe Brexit strategy, compared to just&nbsp7.4 per cent who said they had been adequately consulted.Change.org&nbspsurveyed more than 89,000&nbspusers in the UK between October 31 and November 5, of which 63 per cent backed Remain, a quarter voted Leave&nbspand the remainder either did not vote or chose not to say.Half of respondents believe their MP had failed to represent them properly over Brexit, compared to 16 per cent who said their MP had represented them fairly. A third of those who replied were undecided.&nbspThe majority (63.3 per cent) backed a second referendum when asked how the government could give people a say on the terms of Britain’s exit from the bloc, while 10.9 per cent suggested a public consultation.About 10 per cent said they trust the government to do a good job, and 7.4 per cent said the UK should just leave the EU.Kajal Odedra, executive director of change.org UK, said people feel “bombarded but gagged by Brexit”, regardless of whether they voted to leave or remain in the European Union.EU to decide whether Brits will need visas in event of no-deal BrexitVoters in most vulnerable Tory seats 'back fresh Brexit vote'Every day takes us closer to giving the people the final say on BrexitThornberry says Labour could still back Final Say Brexit referendumCorbyn rejects calls for Final Say referendum, despite Labour backlashJohnson insists May can be forced into Final Say referendum on BrexitWriting exclusively for The Independent, Ms Odedra said: “The choices the government makes in negotiations are critical.&nbsp“But they are being made far away from the public with no consultation whatsoever.&nbsp“When we asked change.org users, only 7 per cent of those polled felt they have been given a chance for their voices to be heard since the referendum.“And 85 per cent felt they didn’t have any say in shaping the government’s Brexit strategy.”Leave voters were more likely to feel heard by ministers at about 23 per cent, while only 1.4 per cent of Remain voters said they had been listened to, according to the poll.Young people were also more likely to feel ignored than older voters, the findings show, with just 8.3 per cent of 16 to 24-year-olds reporting that they believe their voices are being heard.Around a quarter of over-65s said they felt listened to, compared to 20 per cent of those aged 55 to 64, and 10.5 per cent of 25 to 34-year-olds.It comes after a special parliamentary event heard that&nbspmore people back a fresh referendum than oppose one in all of the 67 most marginal Tory seats.The YouGov survey of 25,000 people&nbspalso found that a majority of voters in the Labour constituencies that voted Leave in 2016 now back a fresh referendum, by an average of 59 per cent in favour compared to 41 per cent against.It also comes as more than 3,000 people were expected to attend a major rally in London to urge&nbspMPs&nbspto reject a bad Brexit deal.Cross-party MPs have backed the call,&nbspincluding Tory Jo Johnson, who resigned from government last week over Theresa May’s Brexit strategy, Labour’s David Lammy and SNP&nbspWestminster leader Ian Blackford.Liberal Democrat MP&nbspLayla Moran, who backs the Best for Britain campaign,&nbspsaid: “No one voted for this pathetic little deal which actually hands over our sovereignty, making the UK a rule taker rather than a rule maker. It is the opposite of taking back control.”Caroline Lucas, former Green party co-leader,&nbspadded: “The only solution is to take the final decision out of the hands of deadlocked politicians, away from the backroom deals, and give it back to the public with a People’s Vote.“On Brexit, it’s clear we have a parliament in stalemate that can’t deliver a clear choice for the future. So it’s time to let the British public do it instead.”The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? title: fracking china foreign aid shale gas climate change environment dfid funding promoting
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsExclusive: ‘It is a flagrant misuse of the UK’s aid budget to fund the fossil fuel industry overseas when the priority must be shifting to low carbon energy and boosting climate resilience’Click to followIndy PoliticsTaxpayers’ money earmarked to support overseas development has been spent on supporting China’s fracking industry, The Independent can reveal.The government is required to spend 0.7 per cent of its national income each year on foreign aid.But even with climate change threatening the developing world with droughts, flooding and heatwaves, millions have been spent on fossil fuel investment abroad over the past two years.This includes two schemes aiming to “export the UK’s expertise in shale gas regulation” to China, as controversy about new drilling sites rages back in Britain.Tories line up to criticise government’s ‘bonkers’ fracking plans“Global efforts to tackle poverty are now taking place in a rapidly changing climate which is driving more extreme weather, more acute disasters, and hitting the poorest first and hardest,” said Tom Viita from Christian Aid.“It is a flagrant misuse of the UK’s aid budget to fund the fossil fuel industry overseas when the priority must be shifting to low carbon energy and boosting climate resilience.”In a report seen by The Independent, energy watchdog Platform revealed £2m from the government’s Prosperity Fund for overseas economic development has been used to expand the oil and gas sectors in nations including Brazil, Mexico and India.While the fund is allowed to be spent on fossil fuel development, given that one of those UN goals is to urgently combat climate change, campaigners questioned why it was financing 16 projects extracting these&nbsphigh-polluting fuels.Created with Sketch.How fracking works and where it could happen Show all 2Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.They also criticised the use of money explicitly set aside to “reduce poverty” to build projects that&nbspoffer a helping hand to UK businesses.Theresa May announced over the summer that money from the foreign aid budget could be spent on boosting the British private sector abroad.Twelve of the 16 fossil fuel projects supported by the Prosperity Fund between 2016-2018 made references to creating opportunities for&nbspcompanies in other nations including the UK.Anna Markova, who authored the report, said this hinted at why certain projects had been chosen, with British firms like BP known to be exploring shale gas extraction in China.May makes ‘unashamed’ vow to use aid to boost UK firms in Africa“They are kind of going: ‘well, where are the big oil and gas deposits that British companies want to access – OK, let’s go there’,” she said.Kate Osamor, the shadow international development secretary, said: “The Tory government using the UK’s aid money to help their friends in the oil and gas industry get rich is a disgraceful misuse of the UK aid budget.“It is an insult to the British public and our climate change commitments to be doing this at the same time that the world’s leading climate scientists are warning that we only have a matter of years to halt a climate catastrophe.”Ms Markova said the funds should instead be exclusively supporting a global transition away from fossil fuels towards renewable sources.&nbsp“They are kind of shooting themselves in the foot, because they know their mission is to support the transition to a zero carbon economy,” she said.Freed fracking protester vows to keep fighting for environmentFracking halted in Lancashire for third time after biggest tremor yetFury and fruitcake: the nanas fighting frackingChina has one of the world’s largest reserves of shale gas, but extracting it would require fracking on a massive scale. This would&nbsphave enormous water requirements in a nation already facing a national freshwater shortage.With a total spend of over £13,000, the two UK-backed projects were intended to export British expertise to kick-start proceedings and see pilot projects established in China within three years.Given the local opposition, legal troubles and environmental issues that have plagued British fracking, campaigners questioned the government’s involvement in operations overseas.“It is quite unbelievable that the UK should have the hubris to suggest that it can export a regulatory system that is clearly not fit for purpose,” said Barbara Richardson, a spokesperson from Frack Free Lancashire.Energy minister Claire Perry has emphasised the importance of shale gas as a relatively clean “bridge fuel” that will allow the transition to a low carbon economy, but critics are dubious about this goal.“With fracking and any other form of fossil gas, there is a huge risk of lock-in – which means that it won’t get up and running fast enough, and when investors are putting money into these operations they are putting it in for 40 or 50 years,” said Ms Markova.“In 40 years’ time we should not be using any fossil fuels whatsoever.”To meet its commitments under the Paris climate agreement, she concluded that the UK must stop financing any more fossil fuel extraction in foreign countries.Rose Dickinson from Friends of the Earth, who collaborated with Platform and Christian Aid to produce the report, said: “Our government’s claim to be climate leaders cannot be taken seriously while it continues to push fracking at home and abroad.“We need to be moving away from fossil fuels, not showing other countries the best way to dig up more.”Responding to the report, a spokesperson from&nbspthe&nbspForeign and&nbspCommonwealth Office said:&nbsp“The UK’s aid investment is creating a safer, healthier and more prosperous world and is in the UK’s interest.“Gas has the potential to be a reliable energy source as countries transition towards a clean energy future, and these programmes are aimed at sharing UK expertise to help ensure that their exploration or development of resources like natural gas is done to high environmental standards.”The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit title: theresa may brexit deal renegotiate cabinet ministers plan leave eu
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe prime minister will visit Jean-Claude Juncker this week for further talks focussing on the outline future relationshipClick to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May has played down hopes of changing Britain’s draft withdrawal deal in a move that will concern Brexiteer cabinet ministers demanding it be re-written.The prime minister announced that she would visit European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker&nbspthis week for further talks, but said the focus would be on the future relationship.A group of cabinet ministers are attempting to secure further changes to Ms May’s plans – in particular&nbspin relation to the so called “backstop” – but Ms May instead made a determined defence of the arrangement setting&nbspout what happens with the Irish border after Brexit.Corbyn says he does not know how he would vote in fresh referendumThe Independent understands Downing Street is concerned that any attempt to re-open the withdrawal agreement will inadvertently give the EU a chance to tamper with what they believe are positive elements already secured by Ms May.Ms May was speaking to Sky News’ Ridge on Sunday show when she was asked about the possibility&nbspof reshaping parts of the withdrawal agreement ahead of a critical European Council summit to be held in seven days.&nbspAsked if further talks ahead of the summit would include the withdrawal agreement – containing the controversial Irish backstop – or the outline future relationship, Ms May said: “The focus this week will be on the future relationship and when we were in the house of commons a number of members were saying we want more details on that future relationship – that’s what we are working on this week.“It’s the future relationship that delivers on the Brexit vote. It’s the future relationship that actually says this is the right deal for the future for our country.”isn’t going to make the negotiations any easier’The prime minister did repeat the government mantra that “nothing is agreed, until everything is agreed”, but then immediately&nbspdrew a distinction between the controversial withdrawal agreement and the future relations – again pointing to the latter as the area which&nbspwill be important for the government in delivering a favourable Brexit.Ms May’s focus will ring alarm bells with Brexiteers who want key elements of the withdrawal agreement re-written, including a number of ministers in her&nbspcabinet.Leave MP slams Brexit deal because UK will be left with 'no MEPs'Moderate Tories warn anti-EU 'purists' they could turn against BrexitMars bars could run out in ‘weeks’ in the event of a no-deal BrexitIt emerged earlier this week that a group of ministers including Andrea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt, Michael Gove, Liam Fox and Chris Grayling are trying to secure changes to Ms May’s strategy, and even a rewrite of the draft withdrawal agreement – with some said to have held back from resigning in an effort to do so.But Downing Street sources told The Independent: “There are very real concerns that if you go back and re-open the withdrawal agreement now, it will give Brussels a chance to unpick the things that we’ve locked in.Negotiators were deadlocked for almost the entire two years of Brexit talks over what happens to the Irish border if a new trading relationship has not yet been agreed by the UK and EU by the end of the transition period in December 2020.Under these circumstances Brussels’ position was that&nbspNorthern Ireland&nbspat least should remain in the EU’s customs union until a trade deal is set in stone, in order to keep the border with the republic open, but Ms May wanted&nbspa solution where the whole UK remains in a customs arrangement but for a time-limited period.Brexiteers said they would only accept such a backstop arrangement if the UK can pull out of it unilaterally – something the EU has not agreed to -&nbspand it is on this issue that the cabinet ministers will try to make a renewed push in the coming days.Asked about the arrangement, Ms May confirmed said it was a necessary “insurance policy” to assure the people of Northern Ireland there would be no border with the Republic.Asked directly whether the UK would be able to leave the backstop at will, Ms May said: “If you took out an insurance policy and if you were coming up to the point where that insurance policy was being used, and suddenly the people providing that insurance policy pulled the plug on it for you and you were left without that insurance policy, without having any say in it, what would you think?“Actually what we are talking about is a backstop we never intend to use, the EU don’t want to use it either, it’s not the only option on the table, were it to have to be used both sides can review it.”&nbspRegarding a change of leadership, Ms May said it would bring more uncertainty for British&nbspbusiness and people’s jobs&nbspand would risk delaying negotiations and Brexit itself.She warned party rivals thinking of replacing her as Conservative leader that it also would not change the parliamentary arithmetic – which currently looks like no way forward would carry majority support.Pressed over what the government will do in the event a vote on the Brexit&nbsp deal was lost in the commons, Ms May said: “There’s a process that parliament&nbspwill go through, were it the case that the deal was lost then the government&nbspwould come back with their proposals for what the next step was.”The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your being urged to check a vehicle's history thoroughly before buying to avoid becoming a victim of fraudVehicle-clocking devices should be banned after a surge in incidents that are putting motorists at risk of buying dangerous used cars with false mileage, the Local Government Association (LGA) has said.Recent council prosecutions have involved a van sold with 89,000 miles on the clock when it was found to have travelled more than 243,000 miles, and the combined mileage differences on 10 clocked vehicles adding up to almost 240,000 miles, the LGA warned.How to avoid scams when booking your next holidayOne in 16 vehicles being checked has a mileage discrepancy, which means there could be 2.3 million clocked and potentially dangerous cars on UK roads, the LGA said.The LGA, which represents 370 councils in England and Wales, is urging people to check a vehicle's history thoroughly before buying to avoid becoming a victim of fraud.A proposed EU ban on companies providing mileage correction services was supposed to be in place by May this year, and the LGA is calling for the legislation to be implemented as soon as possible and retained under UK laws after Brexit.An existing legal loophole means that while knowingly selling a clocked car without disclosing it is fraud, it is not illegal to alter the odometer's mileage.Simon Blackburn, chairman of the LGA's Safer and Stronger title: bolivia tombs discovered human remains inca artefacts 500 years ago archaeologists
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsTombs contained remains of more than 100 people and&nbspvessels used by Incas for performing death ritesClick to followThe Independent USArcheologist Jedu Sagarnaga holds a skull as part of an archeological finding, dated approximately 500 years ago, in Mazo Cruz, near Viacha, Bolivia, November 12, 2018Tombs containing human remains and Inca artefacts from more than 500 years ago have been discovered in Bolivia.Archaeologists say the remains, which were found at a quarry about 12 miles from La Paz, belonged to more than 100 people from an indigenous civilisation.They were buried with more than 30 vessels used by the Incas for performing death rites.Massive hoard of mummified cats found in ancient Egyptian tombs“The vessels are whole and are Incan,” said Jedu Sagarnaga, an archaeology professor at Universidad Mayor de San Andres, who led the investigation.The site near the modern-day town of Viacha also contained elongated skulls that may have been stretched to differentiate the social rank of iniduals, he said.The cemetery carved into limestone appears to have been built by the Pacajes people, whose cities were conquered by the Incas towards the end of the 15th century.&nbspJedu Sadarnaga shows pottery on November 15, 2018 from one of the tombs found at a Bolivian quarry near the capital of La Paz. The tombs contained remains belonging to more than 100 iniduals and were buried with more than 30 vessels used by the Incas. (APLuis Gandarillas)The Pacajes formed part of the Aymara kingdom and developed around the year 1200 after the decline of the Tiwanacu people in the Andean highlands.Julio Condori, an archaeologist who runs the Archaeological and Anthropological Research Centre in Tiwanacu and was not involved in the excavation, said: “This finding reaffirms our identity and culture and shows that not only was there an influence from the Incas, but from other people as well.”Bolivian Minister of Culture Wilma Alanoca called it an “unprecedented discovery”.Jedu Sadarnaga shows jewellery on November 15, 2018 from one of the tombs found at a Bolivian quarry near the capital of La Paz. The tombs contained remains belonging to more than 100 iniduals and were buried with more than 30 vessels used by the Incas. (APLuis Gandarillas)The site was excavated months ago, but the findings were not made public until this week.&nbspMr Sagarnaga said that in addition to the bones, the burial site held more than 150 decorative bronze objects including necklaces, bracelets, ornaments for women’s hair, large broaches, and two horseshoe-shaped headbands used by nobles.&nbspSnow, sleet and frost to hit BritainWoman blows herself up near police checkpoint in Chechen capitalFrench serial killer gets life sentence as he awaits murder trialBlack Friday 2018 tips for avoiding scams and fake dealsMan, 79, claims he killed at least 90 people over four decades“These were personal favourites of the deceased, whereas the vessels were more for the community,” he said.The archaeologist said the site had been looted in the past, but the tombs were interesting because they held the remains of men and women from different social status.&nbspThe remains were taken to an archaeological centre for further study and will eventually be returned to a museum in Viacha.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: brexit news theresa may eu deal dominic raab resignation
story: Mr Raab resigned from his position on Thursday in protest at the terms of the withdrawal agreement. His decision to quit came less than 24 hours after Mrs May said there was &ldquocollective agreement in the Cabinet on the deal. He has now spoken out to criticise&nbspthe Prime Minister&rsquos negotiation strategy. They can&rsquot be eliminated.&ldquoWe need to be honest about that. But far better that than to allow a pretty controlling and manipulative relationship with the EU to become abusive.&ldquoI don&rsquot think we should look like we&rsquore afraid of our own shadow. We need to be going out there and grasping opportunities.READ MORE: THERESA MAY ON THE BRINK AS SENIOR BREXITEERS HOLD 'SECRET' TALKS ON REPLACEMENT PM&nbsp                The PM&rsquos deal would block free trade with the US, says Owen Paterson                Theresa May receives BACKING from Scottish SecretaryProminent Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg is among those to be calling for a leadership change (Image: )Andrea Leadsom is trying to persuade the Prime Minister to alter her Brexit deal (Image: )His intervention criticising his party leader&rsquos ability to lead the country through the process of leaving the EU comes amid ongoing talk of a plot to replace Mrs May.In order for a vote of no-confidence to be called, 48 Conservative MPs must submit letters demanding a vote to the chair of the party&rsquos influential backbench 1922 committee.So far, more than 20 Conservative MPs publicly admitted to submitting such letters, with others thought to have done so in private.However, so far high profile Brexiters such as Michael Gove and Andrea Leadsom have refused to back the plans to topple the Prime Minister and are working on altering the agreement from inside the Cabinet.Mrs Leadsom said she supports the Prime Minister but suggested there is an opportunity before the special European Council meeting to get the best possible deal for the UK.

story: Ms Braverman made the shock comments during an article she wrote for the Sunday .She was the fourth of a string of Government Ministers to resign on November 15 in protest at the deal.They included Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab and Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, both Cabinet members.                Senior Brexiteers hold 'secret' talks on replacement PMIn the article Ms Braverman argued &ldquothis negotiation is &ldquorapidly acquiring the moniker of &lsquothe worst deal in history&rsquo.She added: &ldquoSimply put, the Northern Irish backstop is not Brexit.&ldquoIt prevents an unequivocal exit from a customs union with the EU.&ldquoWithout a unilateral right to terminate or a definite time limit to the Backstop, our many promises to leave the customs union will be broken.&ldquoSimply put, the Northern Irish backstop is not Brexit (Image:  )Jacob Rees-Mogg speaking outside Parliament on Wednesday (Image:  )According to the draft agreement reached with Brussels the UK will automatically join a customs union with the EU if it fails to negotiate a new trading relationship with Brussels during a transitional period after Brexit, in what&rsquos known as the &lsquobackdrop&rsquo deal.The transition period is currently set at 21 months, though Mrs May has suggested this could be extended.Should the backdrop be activated the whole UK will join the customs union, though controversially there could be ergence on some areas for Northern Ireland.If the UK does end up in a European customs union it will still have to obey a good proportion of EU regulations, and would struggle to sign its own trade deals with other countries.Ms Braverman provocatively claimed much of the negotiating had been done by civil servants without the approval of their political masters.                Theresa May receives BACKING from Scottish Secretary                'Swissexit?' Referendum in Switzerland could lead to break with EUNigel Farage at a 'Leave Means Leave' rally pushing for a hard-Brexit (Image:  )She said: &ldquoThe failure of accountability to politicians was astonishing.&ldquoCivil servants would routinely return from Brussels with the fruits of their endeavours, often having strayed beyond Cabinet mandates or setting policy decisions in legally binding text before Ministers had even discussed them.She added the deal was agreed by &ldquothose who are risk-averse, pro-remain and do not want Brexit to happen.Following the announcement of the deal leading Tory backbencher Jacob Rees-Mogg, chair of the hard-Brexit backing European Research Group, tabled a letter of no-confidence in the Prime Minister.If Graham Brady, chair of the 1922 committee, receives 48 such letters from Conservative MPs it will trigger a formal vote of confidence in Mrs May&rsquos leadership.Anti-Brexit supporters rally outside Parliament  (Image:  )The submission of over 20 such letters have been made public.Ms Braverman also suggested the Northern Ireland border issue had been exploited by those advocating a soft Brexit.She said: &ldquoSadly the Northern Irish border has been confected into a &lsquoproblem&rsquo rather than an opportunity.&ldquoOnly the historians will know whether it has been by design or incompetence.The Government has committed to avoiding a hard-border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, in keeping with the terms of the 1998 Good Friday Agreement.

title: brexit news sell uk cars USA trade deal
story: A RollsRoyce on Rodeo Drive (California) &ndash which have proved a big hit with wealthy Americans (Image: FrankvandenBergh Getty Images)Former Cabinet minister Owen Paterson, who is in Washington with a delegation of MPs, has said his talks with US trade officials last week painted a bleak picture about Britain's opportunities unless the Government delivers a proper Brexit. His concerns come as senior academics say a no deal scenario with the EU is now the best option available for the UK at this late stage. Mr Paterson, a former environment and Northern Ireland secretary, has warned that the PM's deal is so bad it cannot possibly proceed.                'Trump READY for trade deal' claims David Davis                 The PM&rsquos deal would block free trade with the US, says Owen PatersonHe said Mrs May's much-criticised backstop of staying in the customs union and keeping Northern Ireland in the EU's single market could end up being permanent and would be governed by the EU's European Court of Justice.He said: In Washington last week, I discussed the deal with senior US trade representatives. There was real enthusiasm for a USUK trade deal but they were categorical that this would be impossible if the UK does not control its own tariff schedules or regulatory environment. That is exactly the fate which awaits us under the Prime Minister's current plans.Many British luxury brands are popular in the US with Rolls-Royce, which is made here, last year selling almost 2,000 cars, despite the lack of a trade deal. Clothing brands Next, Asos, Lipsy London, Rokit and Sweaty Betty also boast strong sales due to the UK's reputation for quality.Mr Paterson said that Mrs May should not simply stick to what she has secured from the EU.He added: Her best option is to change course and negotiate a wideranging, zero-tariff trade agreement, with solutions to the Northern Ireland border based on existing techniques and processes. Otherwise, she risks failing to honour the largest democratic mandate the British people have ever delivered.Meanwhile, Professor David Paton, chair of industrial economics at Nottingham University Business School, has said poorer voters in Labour heartlands have the most to gain from a no deal with the EU.Owen Paterson (Image: Victoria Jones PA ArchivePA Images)The senior member of Economists for Free Trade and a long-standing Labour member, has said Labour MPs should back Tory Brexiteers in pushing through a no deal if the PM's plans are voted down.Prof Paton pointed out: In the first place, we would no longer be forced to erect huge barriers to trade with non-EU countries, something which forces up the price of food and clothing for hard-pressed consumers. We would be free to strike deals with fast-growing economies around the world and, crucially, we would be able to control economic policy for the benefit of our own workers, consumers and businesses, rather than having to do what works for the EU Commission.He added: Why should we wait until 2022 before the UK is given gracious permission by the EU to abolish VAT on female sanitary products?Professor Gwythian Prins (Image: CH)On the Briefings for Brexit website of pro-Brexit academics, Professor Gwythian Prins has warned that the EU is rapidly collapsing - with economic problems around the euro, its southern economies such as Italy struggling and concerns over Eastern Europe. He said: The Government should have moved away from the rapidly collapsing EU soon after the vote for Brexit two years ago.He also believes that Mrs May's proposed deal is the exact opposite of what people had voted for.He predicted: You cannot negotiate with the EU. We will now leave, to trade with the rest of the world on World Trade Organisation terms.&nbspProfessor David Paton (Image: Youtube)However, the Department for International Trade has insisted that Mrs May's deal will deliver the ability to trade on services, and pacts with the US, Australia and New Zealand can be ratified next year.Services now account for 80 per cent of Britain's export wealth.A DIT spokesman said: The Prime Minister has been clear that once we leave the EU, we will have the ability to negotiate new free trade agreements with the rest of the world. We are already laying the groundwork for negotiations with the US, Australia and New Zealand, and we will set out our negotiating objectives before formal talks begin.Last month, the US Trade Representative notified Congress of the Administration's intention to start talks with the UK for an agreement once the UK has left on March 29.A DIT source confirmed: The US is getting ready to negotiate.

title: Brexit news Nicola Sturgeon Marr Scotland independence UK EU withdrawal latest
story: Nicola Sturgeon tore apart the proposed Brexit deal claiming Theresa May had not considered the plights of Scotland and protecting Scottish interests after leaving the European Union. Ms Sturgeon, a vocal proponent of Scottish independence, in the past hinted she would decide whether to organise a new referendum based on the terms of the final Brexit agreement struck with Brussels. But when asked if she had the guts to officially call for a new vote she said she would wait for the dust to settle.                Sturgeon&rsquos independence hope DISMISSED by Tory MSP who points out FLAWBBC host Andrew Marr challenged the First Minister during The Andrew Marr Show on Sunday: The last time we were talking about this I asked you about another Scottish independence referendum and you said you&rsquod have to wait until you&rsquod seen the withdrawal agreement. You have now seen it, you&rsquore saying you&rsquove read all 585 pages of it.Now you&rsquove seen it what are you going to do?&nbspWhen are you going to have the guts to actually say &lsquoand so therefore we&rsquore going to have another independence referendum?&rsquoThe leader of the SNP was quick to respond: I&rsquoll come on to talk to you, Andrew, as soon as I make that statement.That would be in the not-to-distant future. We have chaos reigning in Westminster just now.READ MORE: David Lidington urges Sturgeon to back Brexit deal for good of ScotlandBrexit news: Marr asked Ms Sturgeon whether she had the guts to call for a new vote (Image: BBC)She continued: I think firstly it is appropriate to wait and see what the House of Commons does with this withdrawal agreement. As things stand just now, it&rsquos not getting the approval of the House of Commons.I will come forward with my views on what I think are the appropriate next steps for Scotland specifically in the not too distant future. But I think it&rsquos reasonable to allow the dust to settle.The implications, the consequences of Scotland not being independent have been very stark in the last few months, and particularly in the last weeks. Scotland&rsquos interests have been sidelined, our Parliament has been ignored.Ms Sturgeon and the SNP had demanded Theresa May consider the option of a bespoke trade agreement for Scotland to mimic a proposed deal for Northern Ireland but the Prime Minister has so far refused her request.&nbsp                May dismantles SNP chief with BRILLIANT point as Commons ROARS                David Lidington urges Sturgeon to back deal for good of ScotlandThe First Minister earlier this week told Scotland's devolved parliament it was reasonable to think the timing of a possible new vote on secession would depend on how Britain's current political chaos over Brexit played out.Ms Sturgeon said: That time will come, and when it does I have no doubt that the people of Scotland will choose to be independent.She likened the deal to being blackmailed into a choice between the frying pan or the fire, claiming it posed a threat to jobs.In a phone call with Theresa May after a five-hour Cabinet meeting on Wednesday, Ms Sturgeon rejected her claim that Scotland's interests had been protected in the deal.The First Minister said: I pointed out that there isn't a single mention of Scotland in the agreement, that it disregards our interests and puts Scotland at a serious competitive disadvantage.&ldquoIt is obvious that the Prime Minister can barely unite her Cabinet on this deal and it is also increasingly clear that she will struggle to get a majority for it in Parliament.In these circumstances, it is more important than ever that we are not faced with a false choice between a bad deal and no deal. No-one should be effectively blackmailed into a choice between the frying pan or the fire.

title: what brexit backstop plan theresa may eu irish border
story: Heres our guide to the plan and what it means for Northern Ireland and its border with the Republic of Ireland.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.The backstop will see Britain remain in the customs union for as long as necessary until an alternative way of keeping the border open is found.Mrs May wants the UK to have the right to end the backstop at will - but the EU has warned that would render the mechanism pointless.It would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.At the same time the UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries.On November , thereported that Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab demanded the right to pull Britain out of the EU’s Irish backstop after just three months.The paper claimed the hardline pitch to the Irish government “stunned” Irish officials.Its claimed Mr Raab’s proposal was put to the Irish deputy prime minister Simon Coveney in a private meeting in London.However, the Irish Prime Minister told Theresa May that he will not accept a Brexit deal which gives the UK the unilateral power to halt backstop arrangements for the border with Northern Ireland.The EU has suggested a backstop that would see Northern Ireland staying in the customs union, the EU VAT system and parts of the single market.This will essentially draw a customs border down the middle of the Irish Sea, potentially damaging the union of the UK.Mrs May has suggested a backstop that will see all of the UK aligned with the EU customs union for a limited time after .Brussels has two issues with Mays plan.The first is that May wants the backstop to come to an end after a certain time period the EU thinks this would be self-defeating as its possible no solution for the Irish border would be found.The EU also thinks this risks leaving Britain benefiting from the customs union and single market for years after Brexit - reaping all the benefits without having any of the obligations that full membership would entail.In June  European leaders said Britain was running out of time to do a deal because of the unsolved border problem.In July Theresa May quoted Shakespeare as she insisted the UK would not be broken up with a border down the Irish Sea. Theresa May has told EU leaders she is looking at ways of keeping Britain under their rules for at least another year as part of efforts to break the Brexit deadlock.Addressing the  national bosses at a tense summit in Brussels on the night of October , the PM said she is “ready to consider” extending the  month transition period after the UK leaves the EU next March.The potentially incendiary move has been drawn up by the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier to try to end a bitter impasse over the Irish border.It would mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest.The news comes after talks on Sunday, October , hit a brick wall once again, as the issue of the Irish border continues to cause a headache for Theresa May.Theresa May has insisted any backstop arrangement must apply to the UK as a whole so not to create a border in the Irish Sea.However, talks broke down after the EU had insisted on a second backstop arrangement - just involving Northern Ireland -the UKs version wasnt ready in time, according to Downing Street sources. Mrs May dubbed the continuing row with Brussels over how to avoid a hard border in Ireland as “the one real sticking point left, but a considerable one”.The Democratic Unionist Party has vowed to oppose any new checks on goods passing between Great Britain and Northern Ireland.Irelands Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, said that EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier indicated that the European Union will allow extra time for talks about the border.Mr Coveney said he was frustrated and disappointed that it was going to take more time than people had hoped.On November , , the PM faced crunch Cabinet showdowns with her ministers where she will set out the details of the agreement she struck with Brussels the previous day.A number of pro-Brexit ministers are feared to be on the brink of walking out over the deal.They believe it would leave Britain tied to the EU customs union for years to come, because of the controversial Irish backstop arrangement.If the Cabinet does block Mrs Mays deal, she could find her position is untenable - leading to a Tory leadership crisis.

title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip side of Britain’s relatively benign rule in India , then you’ll also be waiting for the episode where Jodie Whittaker lands in a Soviet gulag and starts teaching children about the brutal idiocy of Marxism.The BBC just doesn’t do anything other than its own left-of-centre view, these days – or irony by the sounds of things.As it’s just been revealed there’ll be no festive episode of Doctor Whobecause it’s “run out” of storylines.Run out  RUN OUT How the hell can a series run out of ideas when it hasn’t had any yet This Morning, Thursday: “Coming up, at quarter to , the rise of the penis filler, Doctor Ranj is here to answer your questions.”The show’s other penis filler, Martin Lewis, will answer them on Monday.IT seems almost wrong to single out just one programme from Sunday’s beautul Armistice Day coverage, but the year’s most meaningful TV awards should probably all go to BBC’s They Shall Not Grow Old, made by Peter Jackson, whose astonishing film gave a voice, laughter, tears and colour to some of the extraordinary men who survived the - trenches.Those of us who watched it, on Sunday, are unlikely ever to forget the experience. Those of you who didn’t, must catch up with it on the BBC iPlayer.Be sure, though, to watch it right through to the credits’ last chorus of Mademoiselle From Armentières, where it names the veterans who have all long since passed but whose memories and souls have never seemed more alive and unforgettable.“It’s quite hard to put your finger on it.”I’ll bet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. Money is an issue of wellbeing.Financial problems are one of the biggest contributors to orce, mental health issues, losing the roof over your head, custody of children and even suicide. And our nation has a real problem with financial capability.That’s why I passionately believe all our children should have financial education at school. While some may say it’s the parents’ responsibility, that doesn’t work when so many parents are struggling to understand financial issues themselves.In , I was involved in leading the successful campaign to get financial education on the English national curriculum, split across Maths and Personal, Social, Health and Economic education .It hasn’t made much dference. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. It’s also available as a free PDF.I’ve been surprised at how many grown-ups have downloaded it to go through it with their kids, but ended up telling me they’ve learned something too.Companies spend billions advertising, marketing and teaching their staff to sell, yet we don’t get ANY buyers’ training. title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. In the s, Ted Heath and Harold Wilson both knew we would baulk at belonging to a Common Market that robbed us of our national independence.So they hid its true purpose — “ever closer union”, leading to a superstate with one currency. The public was reassured our sovereignty would not be surrendered to any meaningful degree.The Tory and Labour leaders both knew this was a lie. But they kept quiet when signing us up in  and when holding the first referendum in .Voters were betrayed from the start. And the pattern was set.In  John Major signed the Maastricht Treaty, creating the EU, without risking the public vote that saw it initially rejected by the Danes and Irish.In  Tony Blair — who now shamelessly praises fork-tongued civil ­servants for hoodwinking eurosceptic ministers — feared he would lose a referendum on handing new powers to the EU. So he refused to hold it.His successor Gordon Brown, never big on honesty when a lie served him better, pretended this Lisbon Treaty was too insignicant to bother voters with.The EU is founded on deceit. “When it becomes serious, you have to lie,” says President Jean-Claude Juncker. Voters are bullied into reversing inconvenient referendums or denied a say at all.And so to Mrs May, the Brexit deal her Cabinet agreed last night and the revealing EU leak yesterday which makes crystal-clear Brussels’ intentions to keep us in its vice-like grip for ever.That plan being to lock us into its Customs Union for all time, unable to make our own trade deals, powerlessly swallowing its orders and obeying its rules.Our Government knows we cannot legally escape this central pillar of the EU — which we voted to “leave”, remember — without consent from Brussels that it will never give.This is not some minor afterthought, to be bargained away, which is why MPs rejected it in July. It is crucial to the reclaiming of our sovereignty which a .million majority including many Sun readers, voted for in .It is crucial to our post-Brexit prosperity. It looks crucial, too, to whether the deal lives or dies. Yet, knowing exactly what the EU intends for us, the PM still brazenly insisted yesterday that we WILL make our own trade deals.How, Mrs May  We cannot. You surely know it.Do not kid yourself no one is paying attention. The public has been sold a pup again and again. It has had enough.Come clean with Britain. This deal is not wholly without merit. title: lifting weights cardiovascular health advice
story: Both types of exercise improved key measures of cardiovascular health but weightlting was more effective.The muscle-building exercises led to more reductions in body weight and blood pressure and fewer incidences of diabetes.But neither forms of activity improved the amount of artery-clogging fats in the blood, such as cholesterol.It suggests elderly Brits could get more benefit from carrying heavy shopping bags home on the bus than going for a brisk walk.Researchers from St George’s University, in Grenada, analysed the health data and exercise habits of , adults.They found % of those aged  to  engaged in “static” exercises and % in “dynamic” exercises, such as running.The figures for adults aged  and older were % and %, respectively.Engaging in either type of activity lowered cardiovascular risk factors by % to % but the link was strongest in static exercises and in the young.Among the older adults, weightlting lowered blood pressure, body mass index and diabetes but not cholesterol.Activities such as running or cycling only reduced their BMI – but not by as much.Among the younger adults, weightlting lowered body mass index and diabetes only. Dynamic exercises lowered BMI but by a lesser amount.Public Health England suggests  minutes of moderate intensity exercise five days a week and muscle-strengthening exercises twice a week.Study leader Dr Maia Smith said: “Both strength training and aerobic activity appeared to be heart healthy, even in small amounts, at the population level.“However, static activity appeared more beneficial than dynamic, and patients who did both types of physical activity fared better than patients who simply increased the level of one type of activity.“One interesting takeaway was that both static and dynamic activity were almost as popular in older people as younger.“I believe this gives clinicians the opportunity to counsel their older patients that they will fit into the gym or the road race just fine.“The important thing is to make sure they are engaging in physical activity.”The findings were presented at the American College of Cardiology Latin American Conference in Lima, Peru. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Rosalie Contreras, , was reportedly angry at the girl and forced her to strip nude and walk home from a residential road as punishment while she drove.Contreras, of Dade City, Florida, told the victim to get back in the car when another vehicle approached and then hit her.She slapped the victim in the face, punched her in the back multiple times and twisted her breasts so hard it left marks, BayNews reports.Police received a call about child abuse and when speaking with the victim she showed a deputy her injuries.The teen had visible bruising on her breasts and two small red marks on her back, police said.The relationship between Contreras and the victim is not known.The police report says in an interview with the woman she admitted she took the teen to the quiet, residential road because “someone who deputies have not named” would not let her “spank the victim”.She admits to hitting and injuring the girl.The Pasco County Sherf’s Office arrested and charged Contreras with child abuse on Friday.Her bond was set at £,and she was released on Saturday on bail, according to booking records.

title: meghan markle baby birth sister tell all book
story: Samantha Markle, , will release her book In The Shadows Of The Duchess in April or May next year – the same time her sister’s baby is due.She said her book “covers everything” and has vowed that she will “hold nothing back” and tell the world “the truth about the lies”.Samantha told the Daily Star Online: “In The Shadows Of The Duchess covers everything… the world does not know truth total truth…holding nothing back!“From lullabies to lies.. it’s all they’re in my book.“The book covers everything that goes on behind the scenes that the world does not know and trust me there is a lot.”Meghan’s sibling also opens up about being targeted by online trolls and claims she has been a victim of cyber bullying following the royal wedding in May.She also said she had to “stretch” the book out in order to fit the huge amounts of material she wanted to include.Describing the bullying, she said: “They have been reported to the FBI and they were calling in death threats to radio stations, so the FBI and police have their phone numbers and their addresses.”However, Samantha, who has multiple sclerosis and uses a wheelchair, would not give exact details on what will be in the book.But she did hint that the book, which was previously titled The Diary Of Princess Pushy’s Sister, will reveal a huge row between her family which involved Meghan’s nephew.Samantha has taken part in a series of television interviews since her sister Meghan started dating Prince Harry.

title: imam recites muslim call to prayer during a church of england cathedrals armistice concert without permission
story: Video of the imam wearing a white robe was taken last Saturday at Blackburn Cathedral and posted on the internet.The call to worship was part of a performance of Karl Jenkins’ The Armed Manin the nave of the cathedral, organised by the Blackburn Music Society.The second movement is a traditional Muslim call to worship recited in Arabic and the imam was chosen to deliver it by the Blackburn with Darwen Interfaith Forum.Speaking in Arabic, the imam said: Allah is the greatest I bear witness that there is no other God but Allah I bear witness that Muhammad is the messenger of Allah.The recitation was made as part of a concert to commemorate the armistice and was reportedly carried out without the churchs permission.Peter Howell-Jones, the dean of Blackburn Cathedral, told The Sunday Times: “I dont think this should have happened here.If people are going to call for my resignation theres nothing more I can say or do to people to pacy them because actually I agree with their arguments.If the booking was made now the answer would be . . . you are very welcome to do the piece but not the call to prayer bit, he added.According to the Sunday Times he only realised that the Muslim call to prayer was in the piece shortly before it began at .pm and did not want to upset anyone by removing it.Lord Carey, a former Archbishop of Canterbury, said it was important for Christianity and Islam to get on together as world faiths.He said “let’s not make too much of a fuss about it but added “I don’t think that without permission I have any right to go into a mosque and preach a Gospel sermon…and I would make that as a parallel”.

title: madeleine mccann parents meeting with scotland yard detectives to discuss two vital new leads
story: Last week the Home Office confirmed they had provided the politan Police with another £, to chase a “final line of inquiry”.Scotland Yard have been applying for funds every six months to continue the inquiry - known as Operation Grange - that has cost £.million so far.In a sit-down meeting last week with the McCanns the Operation Grange team told them they had “two specic and active” lines of inquiry.A Whitehall source told the Daily Mail: “politan Police officers had a sit-down meeting with Madeleines parents to tell them exactly where they were with their inquiries.“They informed them they had two specic and active leads that still needed to be chased and that although the investigation was taking longer than they initially thought officers said they were confident and hopeful they could get a result.”A senior Government source added: “Police seeking special grant funding have needed to justy exactly what the money would be spent on, who they are chasing and why.“They have had to outline their intended work in full detail and careful consideration has been given but we cannot ulge any aspects of that while there is an ongoing operation.”Madeleine was three when she was last seen while on holiday with her parents in Praia da Luz, Portugal, in May .Former GP Kate and heart doctor Gerry, both , from Rothley in Leicestershire, are “very encouraged” the politan Police could finally be closing in on Maddie’s kidnapper after eleven-and-a-half years.Family spokesman Clarence Mitchell said: “They are very encouraged that the Met Police still believe there is work left to be done in the search for their daughter and they remain incredibly grateful to the Home Office for providing an extra budget for the investigation.It is a boost the while family and gives them renewed hope that one day they may finally find out what happened to Madeleine.Devastated parents of other missing children slammed that decision and questioned why the McCanns were getting “priority treatment”.Paul Whinham, , from Wallsend in North Tyneside, has been searching for his -year-old son Michael for three years.Speaking to the Sun Online he said: “After a six month investigation the Chief Inspector of Northumbria Police told me ‘I’m sorry Paul there’s no more money to keep on going, the case is closed butyou want to declare your son dead it takes six years’.“If any new evidence comes to light,there’s any more sightings or anything, I was told to get in touch with them.”He added: “But then I find out yet another £, is going from the Home Office to the politan Police to keep Operation Grange going.“Even police have said there’s no other evidence, there’s nothing that’s come to light in  years. Why  Why are they keeping going  Why “Why is one family getting all this priority  There are , missing people in this country.”In a separate case Karen Downes, , said she felt “very angry” other children, including her daughter Charlene, were “simply being forgotten”.She told the Sun Online: “A child goes missing in the UK every three minutes. What about all those others who never come home again ”No trace has been found of Charlene, , since she was last seen in Blackpool on November ,  – despite huge publicity and a £, reward.Last year detectives finally released the only CCTV footage of her on the day she vanished - after it lay unnoticed on police shelves for  years.Two takeaway workers were acquitted of her murder in  after a trial heard her body was chopped up and had gone into kebabs.Karen added: If they are going to plough money into the search for Madeleine, then they should do the same for all the children who are missing.She didn’t even go missing in this country – it’s really a matter for the Portuguese police, and yet the money just keeps on rolling in for the search.”Ben Needham’s mum, Kerry, has previously criticised the cash given to the Maddie search, saying it “hurt her”.She said: As Bens mum Im not taking anything away from them. We havent had a fraction of that help.Operation Grange has been one of the longest, most high-profile and costly police investigations in history.Some  persons of interest have been examined and sightings of Madeleine — in Brazil, India, Morocco and Paraguay, on a German plane and in a New Zealand supermarket — assessed.Previously police confirmed they thought Maddie was snatched by a paedophile gang who may have smuggled her over the border or grabbed during a botched burglary at the holiday complex.They have also been keen to identy a woman in purple seen hanging around the holiday flat.The Portuguese investigation of Madeleines disappearance was criticised by the British authorities as being not fit for purpose.Scotland Yard began an investigative review into the disappearance in , on the orders of then-Prime Minister David Cameron.Not one piece of forensic evidence linked to the little girl has been found since she vanished.And despite trawling through thousands of tip-offs and potential sightings, police have not confirmed that a single one was her.A Scotland Yard spokesman confirmed: “We have confirmed that Special Grant funding of £, will be provided to the politan Police Service for the six-month period to  March . This is an ongoing police investigation.”

title: esther mcvey cabinet meltdown brexit deal
story: The ex-Pensions Secretary reportedly became hysterical as she slammed Theresa Mays Brexit plan.Ms McVey today denied that she lost her temper - and described Cabinet colleagues as feeble for getting alarmed by her behaviour.The MP for Tatton resigned on Thursday morning, slamming the PM over the proposed withdrawal agreement.During the crunch Cabinet meeting the day before, Ms McVey was the angriest minister - urging Mrs May to let those present take a formal vote on whether or not they back the deal.One Cabinet source told the Mail on Sunday: It was the most extraordinary meltdown Ive seen in Cabinet.I thought security would have to be called, because she seemed so hysterical and aggressive.Chief Whip Julian Smith ended up shouting at her to shut up, the minister added.Ms McVey today described the claims as hilarious and mocked ministers for overreacting.She said: Seems a bit of straight talking from me to ask Cabinet members to vote on the most important matter in a letime made them crumble!Makes you wonderthis is how feeble senior members have been in negotiations with the EU over our future After she demanded a vote on the deal, Cabinet Secretary Mark Sedwill - Britains top civil servant - produced documents showing that a formal vote is impossible.Ms McVey was one of two Cabinet ministers to resign on Thursday, triggering a massive crisis for Mrs May.The PM is now fighting off an attempt to call a vote of no confidence in her leadership.

story: An estimated .million people have felt the tremors.The earthquake struck about  kilometres from the town of Ravenna.Witnesses and residents say they heard a roar and that furniture moved.One wrote to EMSC and said: I heard a roar.Another said: Very short and intense.One said: Just two seconds of trembling, lamps moving a minute and chair moved.Another added: For about  seconds the TV set and hanging lamp were visibly shaking, I was sitting on couch and could feel shaking like strongwaves.A . earthquake on the Ritcher scale is classied as a light earthquake.It is felt by most people and objects do move and fall as well as light sleepers will be woken up.Signicant damage is unlikely.The EMSC  is an independent organisation that provides real-time earthquake information.For the latest news on this story keep checking back at Sun Online, where we will bring you live updates as soon as they happen, before anyone .Like us on Facebook at www.facebook thesun, and follow us from our main Twitter account at @TheSun, where we will bring you this story and all the rest of the top news and exclusives of the day.TheSun is your go to destination for the best celebrity news, football news, real-le stories, jaw-dropping pictures and must-see videoOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
