title: thousands of worms being blasted into space to find secret to a longer healthier life
story: The tiny transparent worms will be heading to the International Space Station as part of a Government-backed project to seetwo drugs can prevent or slow down muscle wasting brought on by microgravity.Worms are being used because they have a similar muscle structure to humans.They suffer frommuscle loss in many of the same conditions that humans do.In space, the mm long c-elegans worms will have nothing to push against to keep their muscle mass and so quickly start losing strength.This mirrors the impact experienced by the elderly on Earth and those with conditions like muscular dystrophy and diabetes.Experts at Nottingham University are hoping that by either boosting the cell batteries or improving their uptake of calcium will mean they can slow down the process or even prevent it entirely.Dr Bethan Phillips, assistant professor at the university, said: We know that microgravity accelerates the effects of muscle disuse similar to when elderly people are bedbound or are recovering from an injury.Skeletal muscle is linked to many systems in the body, such as the immune system, so the health implications are not just loss of movement, they are far more widespread.The worms have similar muscle to human skeletal muscle so we can seethese pharmaceuticals have a beneficial effect which could eventually lead to new treatments both for astronauts and the elderly.Not only do these experiments offer hope for the elderly on Earth but they will be vital to the success of future colonies on the Moon or Mars.Astronauts can lose up to  per cent of muscle mass on a y mission and . per cent of their bone mass for each month spent in space.Tim Peake was missing nearly  per cent of his bone volume by the time he touched down from his trip aboard the ISS.The experiment is one of several being funded by the UK Space Agency, which has provided nearly £million ahead of the th anniversary of the International Space Station on Tuesday.The government says tackling ageing is one of its grand challenges and it wants to add five extra health years of le by .A team from Liverpool will also be sending tubes of human muscles grown from stem cells to the ISS to seeheat shock proteins could stop the inevitable decline of muscles.In the cells of older people muscles fail to get stronger even when they exercise, which researchers believe could be because of inflammation in the body.Researchers believe the heat shock proteins may help dampen down the impact.Professor Malcolm Jackson, from the University of Liverpool, said: Ageing is one of the greatest challenges of the st century and so the opportunity to use micro gravity to help understand the mechanisms underlying age-related muscle loss is really exciting.There is some evidence that inflammation is behind the problems with ageing muscle andwe can find a way to stop that inflammatory response it could be beneficial.Sending cells into microgravity allows us to look at muscle ageing response in isolation without the other effects of ageing complicating the pictures.The University of Strathclyde in Glasgow will also receive nearly £. million to investigate how shaking a liquid in microgravity includes solid particles to accumulate and from highly ordered aggregates, instead of causing the floating particles to simply disperse.Science Minister Sam Gyimah said: This research will help those with muscle conditions to live longer, healthier, happier lives and is a great example of our modern industrial strategy in action - transforming le on earth through out-of-this-world research.

title: david cameron prime minister brexit steve hilton
story: The ex-PM could make a comebackhis successor is forced to stand down, according to his former guru.Steve Hilton, Mr Camerons director of strategy, said his old boss could be the best hope for Britain.He suggested one reason the Brexit process has been so tricky is that Mr Cameron quit immediately after the EU referendum.Writing in the Sunday Times, Mr Hilton said: What Britain needs above all is a leader with the confidence and the character to command respect and bring people together from all sides of this bruising two-year national meltdown.If there is a Conservative party leadership election, no doubt many able MPs will throw their hat in the ring.But there’s one name that should also be on the list - David Cameron.Considering where we are now, David Cameron’sto No could in fact be the best hope for Britain.Mr Hilton blasted Mrs Mays proposed Brexit deal - but claimed it would have been almost impossible to negotiate a better one.Instead he called for Britain to leave the EU without any deal, and use it as an opportunity to re-imagine the countrys economy.The Sun revealed earlier this month that Mr Cameron is keen toto frontline politics because hes bored s***less.The former Prime Minister left Parliament in , a few months after leaving Downing Street.But he likes the idea of making an unexpected comeback, possibly in the key role of Foreign Secretary.

title: pm must redraw brexit plan
story: But she shows no signs of understanding why our readers are so angry at her concessions.Whatever the merits of her draft plan, the Prime Minister has to acknowledge that this is not what many voters wanted when they opted for Brexit.Her resilience and commitment to the job are not in question.Indeed the contrast between her sense of duty and the incoherent warblings of Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party could not be clearer.But the Prime Minister must give Brexiteers in the Cabinet the chance to shape the political declaration outlining our future relations with the European Union.She needs to redraw the plan and extract more concessions to get a genuine two-way relationship. Only then can she attempt to get the House of Commons to back her deal.Because at the moment that’s about as likely as Jean-Claude Juncker turning down a Christmas drink.MEL B’s heart-wrenching retelling of her abusive relationship is hard to read.It is never easy to speak out, and she should be applauded for doing so.But there are plenty of women who don’t have the profile of a Spice Girl or aren’t aware that the control their partners hold over them is as vicious as any physical violence.The Government was right to change the law to create a new offence of “coercive control”.And with two people dying by their partner’s hand every week, we must redouble our efforts to protect those in unhealthy relationships.OUR Royal snapper Arthur Edwards’ wonderful pictures of Prince Charles show a future King who has never been scared to do his own thing.His son Prince William is clearly built in a similar mould.His comments this week on the dangers presented by social media weren’t just spot on in their tone, but were the words of a young father who, like countless others, fears for our kids.When the time comes, Wills is clearly going to make a passionate, committed Prince of Wales.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit theresa may dominic raab eu deal customs union
story: Raab stepped down as Brexit secretary on Thursday saying he could not accept the terms of the deal done by the Prime Minister.He told the Sunday Times the UK should demand an agreement that allows it to unilaterally leave any customs union.He spoke after two opinion polls suggested the week of chaos in Westminster has badly dented the Conservatives election fortunes, with the Tories now trailing behind Labour.Although there is still speculation in Westminster Theresa May could face a confidence vote, one of her ministers said there is still time for more to be done on the Brexit deal, despite an EU summit scheduled for November  to confirm it.Andrea Leadsom, the Brexiteer Commons leader, said she supports the Prime Minister but suggested there is an opportunity before the special European Council meeting to get the best possible deal for the UK.But Raab told the Sunday Times: If we cannot close this deal on reasonable terms we need to be very honest with the country that we will not be bribed and blackmailed or bullied and we will walk away.I think there is one thing that is missing and that is political will and resolve. I am not sure that message has ever landed.Both May and Raab are due to take their arguments on to television screens on Sunday morning.At the end of a long week for May which left her battered and bruised but still standing, she told her critics that their alternative plans for a Brexit deal would not solve the issue of the Ireland border and the backstop arrangement.She told the Daily Mail: People sayyou could only just do something slightly dferent, have a Norway model or a Canada model, this backstop issue would go away. It would not. That issue is still going to be there.Some politicians get so embroiled in the intricacies of their argument they forget it is not about this theory or that theory, or does it make me look good.Last week saw the departure of Raab and work and pensions secretary Esther McVey, plus the launch of a high-profile insurrection on the backbenches to remove Mrs May from office.She responded by bringing former home secretary Amber Rudd, who quit over the Windrush scandal, back into Cabinet to replace McVey.Steve Barclay took over as Brexit Secretary but with a reduced role.Meanwhile Zac Goldsmith, the Richmond MP and failed Tory London mayoral candidate in , revealed he has joined those who have sent a letter of no confidence in Mrs May to Sir Graham Brady, chairman of the  committee of backbench MPs.Writing in the Sunday , Goldsmith said that under the PMs plan in effect, Britain would remain in the EU, but without having any say.He added: Had that been the choice, I personally would have voted to Remain.The withdrawal agreement we have been presented with is unacceptable to Leave and Remain voters alike.It has close to zero chance of making it through Parliament and with only five months remaining, we cannot afford to waste any more time on it.In a sign the Tory civil war over Brexit is not calming, Middle East minister Alistair Burt warned rebels the consensus that pro-EU MPs should reluctantly respect the  referendum result could break downshe is toppled.Burt, whose role spans the Foreign Office and Department for International Development, attacked a tweet by Steve Baker, deputy chairman of the European Research Group, in which the latter promoted a lawyers legal case against the agreement reached with Brussels.Burt wrote: Be very clear. If an agreed deal on leaving between the Govt and the EU is voted down by purist Brexiteers, do not be surprisedconsensus on accepting the result of the referendum by Remain voting MPs breaks down.Parliament will not support no deal.

title: amber rudd blasts pizza brexit cabinet
story: The new Cabinet Minister took aim at senior colleagues who want re-shape the deal ahead of an EU summit next weekend.She targeted the group led by Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom who have met up in her Parliament office over takeaway pizza.She said: “They are trying to influence the further shaping of the deal, but from what I understand there’s no opportunity to do that. Remember what we’re trying to do, which is to govern.”Rudd, who reveals to enjoying evening whiskies with the PM and husband Philip, also hit out at Eurosceptic Tory MPs including Jacob Rees-Mogg who have sent in letters of no confidence in the leader.She said: “I hope they go back into their corners and we can get on with doing what we’re expected to do, which is delivering a Brexit I hope will protect the economy.”Rudd, forced to quit over the Windrush scandal, said nothing could be “madder” just ahead of next Sunday’s Brussels summit.When she received a call from Downing Street she feared she would be asked to be Brexit Secretary. title: jeremy corbyn brexit deal second referendum
story: The Labour boss also confessed he hasnt read Theresa Mays proposed deal - but has vowed to defeat it anyway.The PM accused Mr Corbyn of playing politics after his admission that hes not familiar with the whole withdrawal agreement.Asked about the -page document, he told Sky News: I have read a lot of it, not every last word - Ive read a lot of summaries and analyses.Mrs May has warned that voting down her deal would lead to either a No Deal scenario, or Brexit being cancelled completely.Quizzed on which of those outcomes he would prefer, Mr Corbyn refused to answer and said: I dont think thats an option were going to be given.He has pushed for Mrs May to call an election to give Labour the chance to take power.But his party also says it could back a second referendum on Brexitthere is no General Election before we leave the EU in March next year.Despite the Labour policy, Mr Corbyn couldnt say how he would vote in a re-run of the  poll.He said: I voted in the first referendum to remain, I voted to remain and reform.I dont know how Im going to vote, what the options are going to be at that time.The party leaders muddled policy was blasted by Tory critics including Mrs May.The PM blasted: He hasnt even fully read it, he doesnt even fully know whats in it, and yet hes going to vote against it.Why  Because hes playing party politics with this.Conservative party chairman Brandon Lewis added: He wants to vote against something he has not even read! Am beyond words!Labour will order its MPs to vote against the Brexit deal when it comes through the Commons next month.But Mrs May is keen to peel off as many Labour backbenchers as possible to balance out the Tory Brexiteers who have vowed to oppose the agreement.The party is also tabling an attempt to stop Britain crashing out of the EU with no deal - eventhe current version is voted down by Parliament.

title: brexit no deal armed forces on standby
story: The Army is reportedly drawing up plans for soldiers to help the police and the NHSwe end up leaving the EU without a deal in March.As many as , members of the military could be deployed under the proposals, according to the Sunday Times.The plans are apparently being overseen by the officers who control Operation Temperer - the Armys contingency plan for terror attacks.As well as helping to keep order and get medical supplies to hospitals, the military could assist with traffic problems near ports such as Dover.Last week Army boss Sir Nick Carter confirmed troops are on standby to get involved in a No Deal scenario.He said: What we always do is make sensible contingency plans for all sorts of eventualities.At this stage, I think people are confident there will be a deal,theres not one then we stand ready to help in any way we can.Defence Minister Tobias Ellwood added: The Armed Forces stand ready to support Britain on a practical basis... We have to plan for every single scenario.Labour MP Alex Sobel, a backer of the pro-EU Best for Britain campaign, said today: To use military bases as a makesht lorry park just goes to show how unprepared the Government are for a No Deal Brexit.This only serves to underline the chaotic nature of this Tory Brexit.Putting the Army on standby is an admission of total and complete failure by the Government.

title: dutch christmas black pete parade netherlands
story: Scattered confrontations broke out between supporters and opponents of the isive Dutch Santa Claus assistant who helps deliver presents to children.To dress up as the Christmas helper, known as Zwarte Piet, people daub their faces with black paint, sparking fierce debates over whether depictions of Black Pete promote racist stereotypes.The character first appeared in an  book by Amsterdam schoolteacher Jan Schenkman, and traditionally, Zwarte Piet is depicted as black because he is a Moor from Spain.As well as painted skin, those dressing up also wear curly wigs, red lips and colourful Renaissance-style costumes.While a nationally televised parade to welcome Sinterklaas in the historic village of Zaandijk north of Amsterdam went off peacefully, parades across the country experienced a number of confrontations between protesters and supporters of Black Pete.Police in Rotterdam tweeted they made three arrests as supporters of Black Pete clashed with anti-Pete protesters, but added that the vast majority of events were peaceful.In the northern city of Leeuwarden, police said they prevented two groups getting into a fight.In nearby Groningen, police separated two groups of protesters to prevent a confrontation.Police in The Hague said riot police kept pro-Pete activists away from anti-Pete protesters as they were escorted to the citys main railway station.Dutch media also reported that soccer fans confronted a small group of anti-Pete protesters in the southern city of Eindhoven.Prime Minister Mark Rutte had appealed for calm on Friday, saying: I think society agrees on one thing: we grant children the magic of the Sinterklaas party.Critics have argued that Black Petes Afro hair, black skin, red lips and earrings are a reminder of the era when the Netherlands exploited slaves, notably in Surinam.But many Dutch strongly defend the character, saying his face is black because of soot from the chimneys he descends to bring presents to excited children.

title: 50 000 sign sky news petition to make tv election debates happen
story: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable, former Green Party co-leader Caroline Lucas, ex-foreign secretary Boris Johnson and ex-home secretary Amber Rudd are among the prominent politicians to have already backed the campaign.All SNP MPs have also given their support, while ex-deputy prime minister Nick Clegg, the Electoral Reform Society, former head of BBC News James Harding, businessman Theo Paphitis and Private Eye editor Ian Hislop are also in favour of an independent commission.Conservative backbencher Daniel Kawczynski became the latest MP to offer his support for the campaign.The Shrewsbury and Atcham MP suggested Theresa Mays decision not to take part in debates before last years election contributed to the Tories losing their parliamentary majority."One of the things that damaged us at the last general election was our leader not participating in the debates," he told Sky News."I picked up a certain amount of negativity on that during the election campaign in my constituency of Shrewsbury."Its vital we establish now, rather than right ahead of the general election, the rules and parameters of these debates."Most people in this country expect the leaders of all political parties to be challenged in a very public and robust way in these debates. title: claw marks and faeces inside kennel housing 70 greyhounds
story: The Trust already owns kennels adjacent to Hillside Kennels.When Jane Thompson, Celia Cross Greyhound Trust kennel manager and trustee, inspected the vacant premises, she said: "I wasnt expecting the kennels to be in great condition... we could smell them from our own property."The stench was overpowering and the foul kennels were in a dangerous state of disrepair. This neglect must have been going on for some time."Nick Weston, head of campaigns for the charity League Against Cruel Sports, visited the kennels on  November and told Sky News: "There are no words for it other than horrendous."The smell alone was appalling. I walked into one of the rooms and the smell just hit me like a wall. It smelled of everything: urine, faeces, damp. It was a hellish mixture of smells." The kennels had been rented by greyhound trainer Tony Taylor, who says he kept  dogs at the site. A number of the dogs were still active racing dogs.Last year, Mr Taylor was given a years notice to move on and told Sky News he removed the last of his dogs from Hillside kennels on  October this year.Mr Taylor says he has only seen some of the photos taken by the Trust and believes "quite a few of the pictures are from a block we shut down about three-and-a-half years ago because you couldnt put a dog in there really".Sky News sent Mr Taylor all of the video and photos to look at and very, but he did not reply.

An exclusive ComRes poll for the Sunday Mirror shows  per cent say she should stay in place until at least Brexit Day on March  next year. That’s two fingers to Tory Brexiteer leader Jacob Rees-Mogg’s attempts to oust her. By an  point margin they say he’s wrong to do so. And only  per cent think he should replace her. There is a virtual tie among those who would like Mrs May to hold on to No after Brexit with  per cent in favour and  per cent against, but that rises to seven in ten of Tory voters.  The last thing  per cent of voters want is for the present crisis to trigger a General Election as Jeremy Corbyn would like. Only a quarter of those questioned would welcome one. But there is some comfort for the Labour leader as the unveiling of Mrs May’s Brexit deal last week means she’s dropped three points. Labour are unchanged on  per cent, Tories on  per cent, Lib Dems on nine per cent. UKIP have gone up two points to seven per cent. Trade-offs have had to be made. “But this is as good as any deal is going to get and no amount of time will change that.”  The  page withdrawal agreement means Britain could be tied to the EU for years to come as we try to negotiate a post-Brexit trade deal with Europe. Voters are not keen either on any of Mrs May’s possible replacements should there be a leadership election. Boris Johnson is favourite, but even he’s only backed by one in five voters, and just a quarter of Tories would like to see him in No. Six in ten would not. Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt scores only ten points, and Environment Secretary Michael Gove eight. Chair of the Tory backbench  Committee Graham Brady is now thought to have received at least  of the  letters needed from Tory MPs to trigger a no confidence vote in the PM.  If she loses that then she must resign and make way for a new PM in a fast-tracked six week contest. If she wins, even by a majority of one, then under Tory rules she cannot be challenged again for a year. Mrs May can hardly call for a confidence vote, though she must secretly want one as it would take  Tory MPs to topple her and that is unlikely. But to be on the safe side Chief Whip Julian Smith has all his junior whips out in force twisting arms. A Tory official told the Sunday Mirror: “It’s sensible for us to prepare for this.” Our poll findings are a blow for the People’s Vote campaigning for a second referendum. The majority of voters do not want one with  per cent against and  per cent for. Andthere was a referendum the result would be too close to call with remainers narrowly ahead on  per cent and leavers on  per cent.  But our results show the sharp ide in age groups with two thirds of - year olds wanting to stay in the EU and the same proportion of those aged over  wanting to leave.ComRes interviewed  GB adults online between the th and th November.THE BAD BREXIT DEAL WHAT THE PM WANTED: No more contributions to EU budget WHAT SHE GOT: A orce bill of poundbillion with more to come ------------------- WANTED: Open Irish border but the same rules to apply to Northern Ireland as the rest of the UK GOT: Open Irish border but dferent regulations for Northern Ireland ------------------- WANTED: Access to EU markets but freedomto trade with the rest of the world GOT: Access to EU markets with no freedom to trade elesewhere until at least  ------------------- WANTED: The European Court of Justice to keepits nose out of British lawmaking GOT: The ECJ will continue to police any single market rules applying to Northern Ireland ------------------- WANTED: A free trade deal with the EU by next year GOT: Vague promise of a future deal ------------------- WANTED: An end to unlimited EU migration into Britain GOT: She got it

title: esther mcvey hysterical cabinet minister
story: NewsEsther McVey so hysterical and aggressive in Cabinet minister thought they needed securityThe former Work and Pensions Secretary quit Theresa Mays Cabinet over the proposed Brexit deal and has been replaced by former Home Secretary Amber RuddShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsEsther McVey leaves after a cabinet meeting at Downing Street "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCabinet ministers were so concerned by Esther McVey s behaviour during the crunch Brexit Cabinet meeting they thought security might have to be called, it has been claimed. Mcvey, who resigned from the Government on Wednesday in protest at Theresa May’s Brexit deal – is reported to have been embroiled in a furious confrontation with the Prime Minister during the mammoth five-hour meeting on Wednesday afternoon. The former Work and Pensions Secretary demanded a vote to formally record Ministers’ positions on the deal, according to the Mail on Sunday who quote a senior figure present. Ms McVey has denied that she was in tears and told the paper: I’m made of much sterner stuff than that. But one Minister present told The Mail on Sunday: ‘It was the most extraordinary meltdown I’ve seen in Cabinet. I thought security would have to be called, because she seemed so hysterical and aggressive.  The Prime Minister tried to talk to her, but it was all just empty waffle which Esther talked over. So Julian [Smith, Chief Whip], just started shouting at her to shut up.’ The Mail also reports that Cabinet Secretary Mark Sedwill objected to Ms McVey’s call for a vote to put on record where everyone stood. Downing Street was left shaken by the resignations of Brexit secretary Dominic Raab and Ms Mcvey the day after the draft of the deal was made public.  But Michael Gove remained in post along with other Brexiteers such as Chris Grayling and Andrea Leadsom. In her resignation letter, Ms McVey said: The deal you put before the Cabinet yesterday does not honour the result of the referendum. Indeed, it doesn’t meet the tests you set from the outset of your Premiership. She added that the deal would prevent future governments from striking free trade deals and ‘threatens the integrity of the United Kingdom’. But May continues to back the deal and says it delivers on the result of the referendum.Although still in the Cabinet, Andrea Leadsom is said the leading a gang of five including Grayling, Penny Mourdaunt, Liam Fox and Michael Gove in a bid to re-write the deal.Ms McVey has been replaced at the DWP by former Amber Rudd, who resigned as Home Secretary after admitting she misled parliament regarding the Windrush scandal. However a subsequent review said she had been let down by officials.

title: tory chief denies sitting on
story: NewsTory chief denies sitting on letters from MPs that could topple Theresa MaySir Graham Brady, chairman of the  committee sayshe had the letters he would tell the Prime MinisterShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  NOV NewsHe says the idea he would do that is offensive "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Sir Graham Brady has denied sitting on letters which could topple Theresa May to give the Prime Minister a moment to draw breathSir Graham is the only man who knows exactly how much trouble the Prime Minister is in. Hes the chair of the  Committee, and is in charge of counting the number of letters Tory MPs have written calling for a vote of no-confidence in her leadership. And he told the BBCs John Pienaar even his we doesnt know how many letters hes received. Asked how many letters hes received, he said: I can’t tell you how many times I’m asked that question everyday. I get asked it in the supermarket, I get asked it walking down the street, and I’m afraid the answer to you is just the same as it is to everybody . He went on: The rules are slightly odd in some ways, but one thing which is absolutely clear in the rules set out in the party constitution is thatany one were to write a letter, and one or two people say they have publicly as you know, then it must be kept confidential, so it’s up to themthey want to say they’ve done it but it would be wrong for me to.  He said that during his eight years in the role, he had experienced both MPs lying about having submitted a letter, and MPs claiming to have withdrawn a letter they had never submitted in the first place. But he said thathe had received the  letters required to trigger the vote, he would have told the Prime Minister. He said: Indeed, the rules are very clear,the threshold were to be reached I would have to consult with the leader of the party – the Prime Minister. Askedthis would happen immediately, he added: Well I think that the whole thing is written with the intention that it should be an expeditious process. I think one of the crazy things that has taken hold over the last few weeks is that people in the media and where are suggesting that this could be something that goes on for weeks, and it’s an entirely discretionary process for me. It’s not. The intention is clear thatit were to happen, it ought to be a test of opinion, very quickly, in order to clear the air and get it out of the way so that the party, the government at the moment, can move on. And he said the idea that he would sit on some letters to give the PM or the party, a moment to draw breath was untrue and offensive.

title: my eczema beautiful  its
story: NewsMy eczema hell left me in hospital and cost me a job - but positive mum pulled me throughCamille Knowles, , shares her journey from hospital patient to health coach, helping others heal their skin holisticallyShareCommentsByLynne Hyland:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsCamille Knowles now has skin under control"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMy earliest memories are of being smothered in cream and wrapped in bandages. My grandma knitted me mittens to try to stop me scratching my eczema at night, but the urge to itch was uncontrollable. I’d wake up with my bandages ripped away, my skin bleeding. Why was this happening to me  By secondary school, confusion had turned to shame. I’d hide my hands because I didn’t want anyone to know my secret. ‘Take your gloves off, Camille!’ a teacher shouted across the classroom one day. The boy next to me stared at my weeping, raw skin. ‘Have you been cutting yourself ’ he asked. At sleepovers, my friends would play with fun beauty products, while I had ugly medicinal creams. Eczema made me feel isolated, painfully aware I was dferent. Winter was the worst. Sore, red, itchy patches flared up on my hands, inside my elbows and across my face. It felt like my body was burning and blistering up from the inside. My lips would swell so badly I could hardly speak and I’d beg my mum to let me stay off school.  Even strong steroid creams couldn’t put out the fire in my skin. Finding a cure was all I could think of. I had dreams, but felt I’d never fulfil them when I was trapped inside my own skin. Mum was a great believer in holistic treatments, and when I was  she arranged for allergy testing. I came away with a long list of foods I was intolerant to and a new optimism. Finally! All the answers were here on this page. I followed that list to the letter, avoiding all ‘problems’ from gluten and dairy, right down to lettuce. At last, I was in control, and my skin began to heal. It seemed like the miracle I’d dreamed of. What I didn’t see then was I’d swapped one problem for another. Instead of being controlled by eczema I was being controlled by my new regime, which was spiralling into an obsession. I’d rather skip a meal than eat the wrong things. Soon I was existing on juices, and although I was exhausted and my weight was in free-fall, I was convinced I was being healthy. But I was running on empty and it was only a matter of time before the ticking time bomb of eczema exploded again. Going to university was the detonator. On top of the tiredness from hardly eating, I was partying and drinking, and by the end of Freshers Week my eczema was back.  It was soul-destroying after I’d fought so hard to keep it away. It was a big part of the reason I quit my course five months later. For a while, my le followed a pattern. I’d be stressed, and my eczema would take over. However,I took myself away from the source of unhappiness my skin would calm down. After that disastrous first go at university, I switched to a study year abroad in Calornia. The combination of sunshine, good friends and healthy living left my skin glowing again. It didn’t last. I came home to start a marketing internship, and what I thought would be the start of my dream career turned into a nightmare. I was out of my depth and shattered by a three-hour round commute. My eczema flared up, worse than ever. I couldn’t drive to work until my then-boyfriend had wrapped me in bandages to stop my oozing, bleeding skin sticking to my clothes. At my interview, I’d talked passionately about my healthy lestyle, yet here I was, a mess. I was told to take time off to recover, but while I was away an email pinged in. I wasn’t the person I’d sold myself as, and they didn’t want me back. I hit rock bottom. Eczema had cost me my internship, and there seemed no way out. One night I was sitting in bed, desperately Googling for eczema success stories, but all I found was negativity. Suddenly, I felt a rush of heat from my toes to my head, and my head was throbbing and swelling.  There wasn’t a single piece of skin that wasn’t burning – my whole body was consumed. When I looked in the mirror, I didn’t recognise the puffy face staring back, and I was so horried I burst into tears. I felt so ill I was frightened I was dying. I was rushed to AE, where blood tests showed my immune system was inflamed and my eczema was badly infected. Beyond that, the doctors had no answers. ‘Sorry, but you’re  and you won’t grow out of your eczema,’ one said. ‘Your best option is oral steroids plus anti-depressants.’ At that point, I’d lost all hope. Thank God Mum was there to pick me back up. ‘You’re an amazing person, Camille,’ she said. ‘You need to focus on who you want to be once you get better.’ So I did. Mum and I wrote a plan. ‘I want to inspire people,’ I said. ‘If I can control my eczema, I’d like to help others.’ First, I had to heal myself. Mum convinced me to try neuro-linguistic programming, which is all about shting your mindset. I thought, ‘This is silly, my eczema is a physical problem, it’s not in my head.’ But after just one session I had my first proper night’s sleep in ages. It made me realise how closely linked my mind and skin are. That’s the moment my eczema truly started to heal. I started making gratitude lists, which sounds wacky but made a huge dference. It’s easy to dwell on the curveballs le throws us, but looking for the positives helps calm the mind and body. I focused on things I was passionate about. I saved up to train as a health coach and natural chef, and the happiness showed in my skin.  I surrounded myself with people who loved me. I also had nutritional tests, which showed I was low in the healing mineral, zinc. I thinkI hadn’t discovered that, I’d have been ill for a very long time. With my own skin under control, I began coaching other people with eczema. It’s been so rewarding, hearing people say I’ve changed their le. Now I’ve poured everything I’ve learned into a book and website, so I can help as many people as possible. I’ll never say my eczema is cured, but I live a le beyond it. I have the occasional flare-up, but I have the tools to control it. Today I truly love my eczema and see the beauty in it. It’s become a friend that shows me when I’m unhappy and guides me onto the right path. Eczema has made me the person I am today.  Camilles H.O.P.E. principles Camille’s programme is centred around four key elements that helped heal her eczema, all aimed at lowering stress. Uncontrolled stress, she says, is a key cause of flare-ups, as it hits the immune system hard.  Home: Make your environment healthier by decluttering , getting enough sleep and practising mindful meditation.  Optimism: You didn’t choose to have eczema, but you can choose how you respond to it. Focus on the positives, reframe the negatives, create a support network, and use affirmations and gratitude lists.  Purpose: Find meaning by doing what you love, from work to family le. P is also for pampering, treating yourself daily with ingredients that don’t aggravate your skin.  Eating well and exercise: A balanced diet plus daily exercise reduces inflammation and boosts mood and immunity.The Beauty Of Eczema by Camille Knowlesis a self-help book to support and empower people with eczema. An online programme will be launching soon at Camille’s website Thebeautyofeczema, visit to sign up to her Beauty Of Eczema Tribe

title: nurse 70 spends retirement treating
story: NewsNurse, , spends her retirement treating people in the world’s most dangerous warzonesDiane Robertson-Bell has spent the last seven years saving lives in places like Syria and YemenShareCommentsByRosie Hopegood:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsNurse Diane Robertson-Bell in Bangladesh"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWith retirement on the horizon, many people would be thinking about slowing down, but Diane Robertson-Bell had no intention of living a quiet le. Instead, she embarked on a new stage of her career, working as a nurse in some of the world’s most dangerous places. After decades working in busy London hospitals and in war zones like Iraq as part of the Territorial Army , she knew she had skills that were desperately needed and had always liked the idea of working for MSF – Medecins Sans Frontier Doctors without Borders, a charity that sends medics to far-flung locations where help is needed most. ‘You see all these terrible images on TV and you think, “I’m sure I could do something to help, evenit’s not very much. I’m sure I could make a dference,”’ says Diane. ‘It was something I’d often thought of doing, but now I found myself without a marriage or mortgage, and I knew I really could this time. My family and friends thought I was a little mad, but they knew better than to interfere.’Diane left her job at the Royal Free Hospital in London aged , and worked shts at her local AE in Welwyn Garden City while she studied for the Diploma in Tropical Nursing she’d need to work for MSF. Five months later, she qualied and accepted a mission to the mountains of Papua New Guinea – the world’s most dangerous country that isn’t at war because there are frequent violent clashes between the  tribes, each of which speak a dferent language. Diane was going to be working in the heart of the country’s most volatile region.  ‘I had to hit the ground running,’ she says. ‘The previous nurse had already left, so there was no handover and I made do with handwritten notes she’d left me. The injuries we’d see were relentless – many of the men carry bush knives and they use them on a regular basis. Every other night I’d find myself preparing people for surgery who had been attacked with the machetes or shot with homemade guns or bows and arrows.’ It was a far cry from the sorts of hospitals she’d worked at in London. The  MSF medics from around the world formed a tight bond, living together in two houses inside the walls of the hospital complex. Security was tight – each morning they were allowed out for a walk or a run, but other than that they stuck to the safety of the compound. Sexual abuse was re, and the hospital had a dedicated unit to treat victims. ‘Domestic and sexual violence are all rolled into one, and are so much a part of everyday le there. Women often come off the worst in troubled times. Our unit had beds where women could stay just to be away from the violence for a while, and we trained local counsellors to try and give them tools to cope.’There was also a maternity unit which sometimes called on Diane for assistance. ‘I’d worked as a midwe many years before, and the obstetrician helped me brush up on my skills,’ remembers Diane. One night when the obstetrician was away, a patient had a very dficult delivery. ‘The baby was completely stuck, and I just couldn’t get it out. I went to the surgeon, who was in theatre and scrubbed up, and he calmly told me that I had to keep trying. Eventually I managed to deliver the baby – it was the most incredible feeling and the mum was very grateful. There were about three or four baby Dianes named after me on that mission –I a go back there, I’ll have to find my little Dianes!’ After nine months, Diane ed to the UK, but she knew even as the plane touched down that her work with MSF wasn’t done. She signed up for another mission, and three months later she headed to South Sudan, where tens of thousands of people had been displaced by the civil war.  Diane lived in a hut with a thatched roof and outdoor latrines full of snakes and spiders. The hospital was rustic and the maternity ward had very little in the way of equipment. ‘We saw many, many babies born weighing just one or two kilos because their mothers were so malnourished,’ says Diane. ‘There were no incubators, so kangaroo mother care – where you put the baby to the skin of the mother and you wrap them up – was all we had. Many mothers were reluctant with this unfamiliar technique, but we had a French paediatrician called David Drummond who’d go into the ward every day and joke and laugh with the women. After a while, a few of them started doing the kangaroo care, and once the others saw how their babies were thriving, they all did it – it just goes to show that one doctor can make a huge dference.’Diane has now done seven missions in as many years, caring for people everywhere from Yemen to Syria. One Christmas Eve, she received an urgent phone call from MSF askingshe could fly back to South Sudan to help with an emergency, and she was on a plane by Boxing Day. Fighting had become so dangerous around the Red Cross hospital that the staff had fled. There were two surgeons, two anaesthetists and two nurses to treat  severely sick and injured patients. With no cleaners left, the hospital was filthy and the MSF team were left in almost impossible conditions. One nurse prepared the patients for major surgeries like amputations, while the other administered antibiotics and fluid IVs to the other patients. The fighting outside the hospital was so extreme that the medical team was only allowed to stay inside the building until .pm each day. ‘It was very dficult to leave people behind, knowing they may not survive the night,’ says Diane. ‘You could try to be the hero and stay, butyou were killed it wouldn’t help anyone at all.So each morning we’d , andpeople had survived, we’d start administering care all over again, andthey hadn’t, then their families would have taken them away in the night. It was really hard.’  MSF offers counselling for their medics after a mission, but it’s not something Diane has had, preferring instead to talk through any traumatic incidents with her colleagues. But there have been some particularly tough occasions that have stayed with her, such as the time in South Sudan when a boat-full of battle casualties was dumped outside the hospital in the middle of the night. ‘It was like nothing I’d ever experienced –  injured people in need of emergency care,’ she recalls. ‘All hands were on deck, including the people who worked in admin or finance at the hospital. I rushed from patient to patient, trying to work out who needed the most urgent care as the finance girl took triage notes for me. There was no time to be afraid we were running on pure adrenaline.’ But there have also been some overwhelmingly good times, such as watching children come back from the brink of death. There is also the camaraderie between the team that makes it feel a bit more bearable. ‘I remember once, over dinner, admitting that it was my birthday that day. Two French girls went into the kitchen, spread some digestive biscuits with Nutella and brought it out with a little candle. I just thought that was the best birthday cake I’d ever had.’ This month Diane turns , she keeps fit by rowing and playing tennis, and is planning one more mission to Gaza before the year is out. ‘There were definitely points during my MSF career where I thought, “What am I doing  I should be at home having a cosy retirement,” but I like to be useful and make a dference. ‘If there’s one thing my time with MSF has really taught me, it’s just how under-appreciated the NHS really is. When people say it’s like Third World healthcare  Trust me, it really, really isn’t.’ To donate to MSF, go to msf.org.uk , or visit Diane’s JustGiving page, Justgiving fundraising Diane-Robertson-bell.

title: 200 hour escort mum who
story: News£-an-hour escort mum who smashed baby sons skull is awarded COMPENSATIONElizabeth Wilkins, , from Plymouth, is facing jail for leaving her baby boy fighting for his leShareByStuart Abel:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsElizabeth Wilkins was attacked during a lunchbreak as she gave evidence "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who left her baby son with brain damage after attacking him has been awarded compensation. Law student Elizabeth Wilkins, , was attacked during her trial on charges of child cruelty, which she denied. However having been found guilty Wilkins, who once worked as a pound-an-hour escort, faces years in jail for leaving her son fighting for his le. She fractured her baby’s skull and broke his ribs by squeezing and shaking him and banging his head against a hard surface in rage and frustration, reports Plymouth Live. The child, only three months old at the time of the attacks two years ago suffered brain damage. Wilkins was attacked outside Plymouth Crown Court during a lunchbreak as she gave evidence.  A judge called the assault “outrageous”, but Wilkins carried on from the witness stand after lunch with no visible injury. Claire Moore, aged , was dragged before city magistrates where she admitted assaulting Wilkins by beating – the lowest type of assault. Moore, of Greenbank, was fined pound, ordered to pay pound victim surcharge and pound compensation to Wilkins. The exact nature of the assault is not known but Plymouth Live understands the former University of Plymouth student was verbally abused and then manhandled in September . Trial Judge Peter Johnson told the jury shortly after the attack in the third week of the trial: “I am aware that at least one of you saw an incident at lunchtime, an appalling assault on Elizabeth Wilkins. “I think all of you are now aware of this outrageous act committed I think by a woman in drink against someone in the middle of their evidence.” He commended her barrister Piers Norsworthy for stepping in to help his client outside the court – an area popular with street-drinkers. Callous Wilkins tried to sht the blame on her former partner and co-defendant -year-old Erick Vanselow.  He was cleared of failing to protect their son – having earlier been acquitted of assault. Judge Peter Johnson adjourned sentencing for psychiatric and probation reports. He granted her bail but banned her from contact with her son. Wilkins is due to be sentenced on December . Wilkins denied assaulting her child causing grievous bodily harm with intent on September , . That was the day the boy’s head was smashed against a hard surface in the flat the parents once shared in College Avenue in Mutley. She also pleaded not guilty to assault causing actual bodily harm between August  and September  in .  Her trial would have cost the taxpayer tens of thousands of pounds. A jury unanimously found her guilty on both counts after seven hours of deliberations. The exact events which ended in the boy, who cannot be named by court order, in hospital will never be known. The jury found that Wilkins attacked her son several times, fracturing his ribs and then pointing the finger of suspicion at Mr Vanselow. She finally banged his head against a heavy object while she was alone in the flat for  minutes on September , . Wilkins said nothing of what happened and the parents only took him to the GP – who immediately phoned for an ambulance.

story: NewsAmbulance chiefs hire handwriting experts to identy staff that defaced unisex signsNHS bosses are trying to find out who in the London Ambulance Service has written graffiti on toilet and changing room doorsShareCommentsByPippa Allen-Kinross:,  NOV NewsThe London Ambulance Service is trying to be more inclusive of LGBT staff "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAmbulance bosses have hired handwriting experts to try and identy staff members who defaced signs in gender-netural bathrooms. The London Ambulance Service has introduced unisex toilets and changing facilities across the capital, but some NHS workers have been making their displeasure clear.The Times reported that NHS bosses claim new signs identying the unisex facilities have been defaced, with some workers ripping them down and others having taken a permanent marker... to make changes. The service has been trying to become more inclusive for transgender people. title: couple told say bye premature
story: NewsCouple told to say goodbye to son born at  weeks reveal incredible recoveryNoah has suffered two cardiac arrests, more than  blood transfusions, undergone heart surgery and overcome more than eight infections after his birth at Liverpool Womens HospitalShareCommentsByCatherine Murphy:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video parents-told-say-heartbreaking-goodbye-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple who were told to say goodbye to their baby boy just moments after he was born premature at  weeks have spoken about his rollercoaster recovery. Noah has suffered two cardiac arrests, more than  blood transfusions, undergone heart surgery and overcome more than eight infections in his tiny  day le. He also had bleeds on the brain, acute renal failure and five lumbar punctures - but dad Paul Gleeson said these were only a few of the procedures the brave little boy managed to pull through. Paul, , and we Emmas ordeal began when she started bleeding in July this year, reports the Liverpool Echo. Emma, , rushed to hospital and was told she would have to deliver him just short of  weeks early.  Doctors at Liverpool Womens Hospital had tried a number of procedures to delay labour, but they soon realised delivering Noah early was the only option. Paul said: It was scary. We then had to make decisions about what our wishes werethings went wrong in labour with Noah. We had to make this decision quick. We were told a c section would cause a high risk to Emma and not benefit Noah. We told themhe needed resuscitating to try everything they could but then we did not want Noah to be put through anything that was not beneficial for him. After Emma gave birth we thought things were going to be OK as doctors showed us Noah so for the first time we relaxed. But then they said to come through and say goodbye.  I went through and there were doctors working on Noah at the same time. He had been taken into intensive care and was in an incubator which had steamed up due to the ventilator pumping fast air into the baby. It wasnt nice to see any baby like that never mind your own. The doctors were amazing with us and Noah. They did everything they could, even helping us to get him baptised that night. After this I went back into our room and we were just devastated, Noah was our first child, he was our dream and we were devatasted. Thankfully, Noah exceeded doctors expectations and survived his first night, and his second, his third and so on. After being born on July ,  Noah remained in hospital for  days.  Paul listed all the things his son went through during this time, including two cardiac arrests, a double resuscitation, more than  blood transfusions, more than eight infections and heart surgery. He also said he had bleeds on the brain, acute renal failure, five lumbar punctures - but he admitted this list is only what he could remember after their rollercoaster journey. Paul added: It seems short listing it like that, but experiencing it was very dficult. During the first month, there was a worry Noah just wouldn’t make it. At one point he was on the max of every medication he could be on and was just stable. Should he have become unstable, we would have had to have a dferent conversation about making him comfortable. However Noah being a fighter, never gave up.  Every time a nurse went off sht you could tell they didnt expect to see him again. It was two weeks after he was born we got our first bit of hope as Noah made the smallest bit of progress. It was strange because once we got this first bit of hope then everyday we were getting a bit more good news. It was three weeks before we could hold him, which was dficult. Because of all the tubes it was a two nurse job to get him out of the incubator. They always said on the unit that it is a rollercoaster journey and that is what it was. After battling against the odds, Noah was finally allowed home on November  - the date he was due to born. Paul added: Hes amazing. We are very lucky that he has came through with very little problems.  He came home on a tube of oxygen and we need to be extra careful over the winter months ashe gets a common cold it get put him back in hospital. He has Chronic Lung Disease but doctors believe he should outgrow this as he gets older. When he was in hospital our family moved baby stuff we had bought out of our house in case he never made it. So its been nice being home and being able to get it back and start doing the baby room. Before we left even the doctors and nurses who had treated Noah were surprised how well he has done. We have so much appreciation and thanks to the Liverpool Womens Hospital and the Neonatal unit, the nurses and the doctors on the unit do amazing work for all the babies whilst supporting us parents too during what is the most dficult time for any parent. Without their love, care and support Noah would not be here for anyone to show any interest. Paul and Emma decided to set up an Instagram account documenting Noahs journey in a bid to help others in a similar situation. Speaking about their decision Paul said: We originally created Noah’s Instagram account so we could update friends and family on his journey. We found lots of people messaging us for updates which was upsetting especially in the early days, so we thought we would do this to document his journey and share with our family and friends. It soon grew to friends of friends and everyone was interested and hoping for the best for Noah. Our thoughts with it now is to continue to update Noah’s journey and development now he’s home and more importantly hopefully provide hope and comfort to other premature parents who, like us, would be frightened and unsure. We found similar hope in a private Facebook group for parents of the NICU unit. Our story is a happy one in that we got to take Noah home. However there are many parents who aren’t as lucky as us. It’s a real dficult journey andthis can bring a smile to people and give parents hope that no matter how bleak, there is always hope we will be very happy. You can follow Noahs journey on Instagram @noah_gleeson. A JustGiving page has also been set-up to raise money for Liverpool Womens Hospital and Neonatal Unit. You can donate at justgiving fundraising challengefornoah .

story: NewsEE and Virgin Media refunds: How to find outyou are owed part of the millionsThousands of phone and broadband customers across the UK could be due a hefty refundShareCommentsByZara Whelan:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsAround , EE customers who ended their contracts early were overcharged "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCustomers are being urged to contact Virgin Media and EEthey believe they are due a refund after the telecommunications giants were found to have overcharged thousands. story: NewsMeghan Markles sister to release "hold nothing back" book when royal baby expectedWhile the Duchess of Sussex prepares to deliver a new royal baby, expected in April or May, her -year-old sibling is due to release “In the Shadows of The Duchess”ShareCommentsByMirror:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsSamantha Marke is due to release “In the Shadows of The Duchess” next year "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSamantha Markle has vowed to “hold nothing back” when she releases her new book - around the same time her sister is expected to give birth to a royal baby. story: NewsMeghan Markle told to dress more like a royal and less like a Hollywood starThe Duchess of Sussexs fashion choices are said to have caused some tension with the QueenShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsMeghan Markles fashion choices havent always been popular with the royals, according to reports "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle has been told she needs to start dressing more like a royal and less like a Hollywood star, according to insiders. title: organised mum shares top housekeeping
story: NewsThe Organised Mum shares top housekeeping tips for chore free weekendsManchester mum Gemma Bray has amassed thousands of online followers after creating The Organised Mum MethodShareCommentsByEmma GillPippa Allen-Kinross:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video secrets-of-the-organised-mum-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum of threes housekeeping tips are followed by thousands, after she created The Organised Mum Method to keep weekends free of any chores. Gemma Bray, , goes by the name The Organised Mum and has devised a method for getting all the cleaning done in half an hour a day between Monday and Friday. After making a rota for herself to help her keep on top of the housework when she had her first child  years ago, The Organised Mum Methodis now religiously followed by parents across the country. Gemma was even invited onto Good Morning Britain to talk about it. Gemma, who is now a mum of three, told the Manchester Evening News : I started the method  years ago after my eldest child was born. I was struggling to keep on top of everything in the house and look after a newborn, so I created the method which enabled me to get everything done but still have lots of time leftover to enjoy my new baby.I sat at my kitchen table and drew it up on a piece of paper and stuck it to my fridge, and I have followed it ever since. Essentially, TOMM is an efficient way to keep on top of everything at home. We work in  minute chunks daily Monday to Friday. Weekends are kept housework free so you can enjoy your time off without having to do a mammoth clean at the weekend. Each day has its own focus room, and these never change.The pattern goes: Monday - living room Tuesday - bedrooms Wednesday - hallway and stairs Thurs - kitchen Fridays - focusing on a dferent area each week in an eight-week cycleThe Friday Focus room alternates each week and gets a deep clean, the idea being that it eliminates the need for spring cleans and makes sure your house just keeps on getting cleaner. Now living in Kent, Gemma is originally from Altrincham in Greater Manchester where she worked in her familys fish and chip shops. Before having children she owned chip shops herself in Suffolk, and it was while still working  days there that she first started TOMM - doing  minutes in the morning and  minutes at night.  Its taken off so much that it recently became her job, with revenue from sponsorship and collaborations with brands so that she can keep her method free for people to download. She said: I never really expected it to take off. In fact, I followed TOMM privately for years and it was only a couple of years ago, one New Years Eve, when my kids dared me to start an Instagram page all about it. I took them up on their dare. It really struck a chord and people started to share the method and it really gained traction quickly. I first noticed it was starting to make some waves last Christmas, when I was asked to go on Good Morning Britain to talk about it. Gemma, who is married to Mike, , and mum to Tom, , Jonny, nine, and three-year-old Ben, puts part of the success down to the team spirit that comes with TOMM. She said: Not many people enjoy cleaning but unfortunately we have to do it. I try my best to make cleaning fun, I put together daily Spoty playlists for people to rock the housework to and the sense of community that people feel when they know that thousands of others are cleaning their living room at the same time is amazing. I think so many people have joined Team TOMM because it gives them motivation to keep on top of the housework without having to be cleaning for hours every day. The team spirit is amazing and on the Team TOMM Facebook group we have such a strong sense of community - we currently have , members. If someone is having a bad day or needs cleaning tips everyone rallies round. It is actually lovely to see. And its not just mums who are on board with Gemmas plan. TOMM promotes a balanced approach to keeping on top of it all, which means it is achievable for busy people, she said. Sht workers, busy parents, non-parents can all follow the method - plus, it is completely free to download.

title: voice sunday mirror now not
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Sunday Mirror: Now is not the time to topple Theresa MayIt is time now that politicians listened to the people they serve. Our ComRes poll today shows there is no appetite for getting rid of Mrs May before Brexit is concludedShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsopinionPrime Minister Theresa May in the House of Commons last week"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJacob Rees-Mogg’s Brexiteers are a rum lot. In their desperation to bring Theresa May down, they may lose Brexit altogether. If Parliament rejects the PM’s deal, MPs would not vote for the horrors of no deal. They will only have one option left to them and that is to postpone or withdraw Article  and stay in the EU. We agree with Mr Rees-Mogg that Mrs May is offering us a lousy Brexit. This newspaper has always believed that nothing could match what we will lose by leaving Europe. But we respect the will of the British people and so leave we must. Mrs May brought many of her present shytroubles on herself. She insisted on red lines she could never stick to and triggered Article  too early to come up with a realistic Brexit solution.  With ministers falling like nine pins, her Cabinet in disarray and a leadership challenge in the offing, strong and stable she is not. However, the Sunday Mirror argued long before she did that the only way to keep the Irish border open was with a UK-wide customs union. It is time now that politicians listened to the people they serve. Our ComRes poll today shows there is no appetite for getting rid of Mrs May before Brexit is concluded. There is no appetite either for a second referendum. Andthere was one, our findings suggest the result would be too close to call. A narrow Remain win would not settle the issue and would destroy Leavers’ faith in democracy. Mr Rees-Mogg should also take note that only a quarter of those questioned would favour a General Election as a response to the mess the Tories have landed us in. There is a time for a General Election to sweep the Tories from power. But that time is not now.  Tragic mistake If the Tories could tear themselves away from Brexit, they might consider the despair their methods are causing ordinary people. A pincer movement by the NHS, the DWP and a local authority drove Penny Oliver to kill herself with the very drugs which got her into a spiral of debt. What started as a small repayment of pound soared as penalty fees and surcharges were swtly slapped on. And Penny could not cope.  Of course the NHS needs to police free prescriptions. Of course it must check whether patients are entitled to claim them. But Penny’s only crime was to make an honest mistake. And then she was disgracefully hounded for money she did not have. The job of the NHS is to save lives. Not to contribute to ending them.

title: workaholic hurricane meghan markle shakes
story: NewsWorkaholic Hurricane Meghan Markle shakes up staff with am startsIn just six months the Duchess of Sussex has really set out to make her mark and do things the way she wants - all in a family that has stuck with strict protocols for centuriesShareCommentsByRachel Endley :,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsInsiders say the royal household has been hit by Hurricane Meghan this year "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle was only officially welcomed into the royal fold six months ago, when she married Prince Harry at their lavish wedding in Windsor Castle this May. But in that time it appears the Duchess of Sussex has really set out to make her mark and do things the way she wants - all in a family that has stuck with strict protocols for centuries. She is the first woman of African-American descent to marry into the heart of the Royal Family, and a orcee, to boot. And alongside her publicised engagements, Meghan has been conducting a series of ‘undercover’ missions to meet the British people, particularly those associated with good causes. It may be this seismic change that has led to the flurry of change in royal staff over the past few month. Just a few days ago it emerged that Meghans personal assistant has resigned just six months into the job. The aide, identied only as Melissa, is believed to have quit suddenly, shortly after Meghan married into the Royal Family in May.  She will soon be joined by the royal couples private secretary Samantha Cohen, who is set to leave in Spring , and follows Harrys right hand man Edward Lane Fox out of the palace door. Senior communications secretary Katrina McKeever – a point of liaison for Meghan’s family – also quietly left the Kensington Palace press office in September. Some who remain, meanwhile, conduct themselves in ways that might seem unorthodox, with Meghan’s private assistant secretary filmed appearing to shove a photographer away from her boss on the recent Australia tour.  In her first royal engagement after getting married on May  many commented on how she appeared to have altered her style to be more fitting with the royals . But just a few months later she was back to her more usual style - showing bare legs in shorter styles, not entirely keeping with royal protol. Since, a source from one of the fashion teams which has visited Kensington Palace told The Mail on Sunday: Meghan is being told she needs to start dressing less like a Hollywood star and more like a Royal.

title: haunted mirror possessed ghost titanic
story: NewsHaunted mirror possessed by the ghost of the Titanic captain up for auctionThe -year-old mirror is believed to be possessed once a year by Edward John Smith, who left it on the dressing table of his home in Stoke-on-Trent before he set sail on the ill-fated ships infamous maiden voyageShareCommentsByDan Coles:,  NOV NewsAuctioneer Richard Winterton with Captain Edward Smiths mirror "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA haunted mirror believed to be possessed by the ghost of the captain of the TITANIC is set to go under the hammer for more than pound,. The -year-old mirror is believed to be possessed once a year by Edward John Smith, who left it on the dressing table of his home in Stoke-on-Trent before he set sail on the ill-fated ships infamous maiden voyage. A servant of the captain, Ethelwynne, was offered to take one item from his home when he went down with the ship after the vessel hit an iceberg on April ,  as a keepsake and in lieu of wages. But the terried maid told relatives she could still see Captain Smiths face in the silver-framed easel mirror each year on the anniversary of when the Titanic sank. Since then, the haunted mirror was passed down by Ethelwynnes relatives and was later discovered in a deceased estate in Wolverhampton before coming into possession of current owner David Smith, who kept it in a vault for the last five years.  The letter, penned by Ethelwynnes sister-in-law Hilda and addressed to someone called Ida, chillingly reads: She [Ethelwynne] always spooked me when she said that at times she could still see Captain Smiths face in it on the anniversary of when the Titanic was sunk. Auctioneer Richard Winterton said: The last time Captain Edward John Smith saw his own noble, bearded visage before leaving home to take the helm of the Titanic was possibly in this very mirror. Even with ones feet firmly on land and in the sunshine of a clear afternoon, there is something otherworldly about seeing your own reflection in such an object.  Captain Smith must have surveyed his own image in this mirror countless times and the legend that his face can still be seen in it on each anniversary of the Titanics sinking is as compelling as it is chilling! Whoever buys this in December will have it in good time to test that legend for themselves on the th anniversary next April. The mirror is expected to fetch more than pound, from collectors when it goes up for auction in Lichfield, Staffs, with Richard Winterton Auctioneers this December.  Included with the mirror is a small brown envelope containing the handwritten note and explaining the items provenance. A statue of Smith was unveiled in Lichfields Beacon Park in July , with the cathedral city chosen as the location due to Lichfields status as the centre of Staffordshires diocese. The plaque on the memorial statue commemorates Smiths great heart, a brave le and a heroic death, adding in quotes Be British - a reference to Smiths stf upper-lip in the face of impossible adversity and what were widely believed to be - yet unsubstantiated as - his final words.  Bargain Hunt and Dickinsons Real Deal star Richard added: Interest in the Titanic is as strong as ever. This mirror could fetch well in excess of pound, at auction. Last month, a couple was left terried after the ghost of the captain of the Titanic photobombed them in a historic pub with connections to the doomed ship. Cheryl, , and Luke Arkless, , hit the headlines after they visited Belfasts Robinsons pub and snapped a romantic shot together they were horried to spot a spooky face right behind them - which they believe bears a great resemblance to Captain Smith.

title: dundee boss jim hails the impact of new signing martin woods
story: Jim McIntyre hailed the impact of new signing Martin Woods on his full debut in the - draw with St Mirren.And the Dundee boss is hoping the former Ross County midfielder can build a telling partnership with Glen Kamara in the middle of the park.The Dens boss thought the two complemented each other well against the Buddies and was impressed with Woods’ staying power, playing  minutes in his first start since May.He said: “Martin was really struggling in the last  minutes.“He felt a wee bit of tightness in his hamstring as well.“He just managed through it to the end as we had made all our subs by then.“But I thought considering he has not been involved in a team structure, then he did remarkably well.“He used his experience and I thought him and Glen looked very strong together.“I don’t want sitting midfielders, I want them to be getting up and around the box.“I thought on Saturday, Glen and Woods really complemented each other, they were excellent.”Woods, meanwhile, is one of a number of players the physio is keeping an eye on over the international break.The Dundee boss added: “Woods has a tight hamstring and Benjy Kallman has a bit of fluid on his knee so we will see how that settles down.“Andy Boyle’s stitches are in a really awkward place on his kneecap.“If you burst the stitches it can take a long time so we have been really careful with him.“Roarie Deacon has a thigh strain but we think it is not as bad as the problem he had previously so, hopefully, we will see him sooner rather than later.”
